The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or
otherwise made available to any retail investor in a member state of the EEA. For the purposes of this paragraph,
a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (a) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1)
of Directive 2014/65 (as amended, “MiFID II”); (b) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97
(the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a “professional client” as
defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II; or (c) not a “qualified investor” as defined in Regulation (EU)
2017/1129 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”).

Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the
“PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in
the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any
retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation.

# PrestigeBidCo GmbH


_Guaranteed on a senior basis by certain subsidiaries of PrestigeBidCo GmbH_


**€315,000,000      % Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2027**

PrestigeBidCo GmbH, a company with limited liability (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung) incorporated and existing under the laws of Germany (the
“Issuer”), is offering €315,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2027 (the “Notes”). The Issuer is an
entity beneficially owned principally by funds advised by Permira Funds (as defined herein).

The Notes will mature on,, 2027. The Issuer will pay interest on the outstanding principal amount of the Notes at a per annum rate equal to three-month
EURIBOR (subject to a 1.0% floor) plus %, reset quarterly. Interest will be paid on the Notes quarterly in arrears on
each,, and, commencing on, 2022. At any time on or after, 2023, the Issuer may, at its option, redeem all or a portion
of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this preliminary offering memorandum (this “Offering Memorandum”). At any time prior to, 2023, the
Issuer may, at its option, redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest
and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, plus the applicable “make whole” premium as described in this Offering Memorandum.
Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the Notes at a redemption
price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to but excluding the date of purchase. See
“Description of the Notes.” In addition, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law.

The Notes will be the Issuer’s general, senior obligations and will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that
are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (as defined herein),
certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any, and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of
the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, if any. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (the “Note Guarantees”
and each, a “Note Guarantee”) by certain subsidiaries of the Issuer (each a “Guarantor” and together, the “Guarantors”). The Note Guarantee issued by each
Guarantor will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of that Guarantor that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment
to such Note Guarantee (including indebtedness incurred under the New Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations) and rank senior in right of
payment to any existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Note Guarantee, if any.

On or about the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured on a _pari passu basis with first-ranking security interests (the “Collateral”) over substantially the same_
assets that secure the New Revolving Credit Facility subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles (as defined therein), as more fully described
elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The Note Guarantees and the security interests will be subject to contractual and legal limitations and may be released
under certain circumstances. The Notes and the Note Guarantees will be effectively subordinated to any existing and future secured debt of the Issuer and the
Guarantors that is secured by property or assets which do not secure the Notes or the Note Guarantees, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing
such debt. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described
in “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”

This Offering Memorandum includes information on the terms of the Notes and the Note Guarantees, including redemption and purchase prices, security, covenants
and transfer restrictions.

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the
listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance that the Notes
will be listed on the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. Settlement of the Notes is not
conditional on such admission. The Exchange is a market designated for professional investors. The Authority has not approved or verified the contents of this
Offering Memorandum. The Exchange is not a regulated market for purposes of MiFID II.

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains non-IFRS financial measures and ratios, including EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Capital Expenditure, Operating Net Working Capital, Operating Free Cash
Flow, Cash Conversion and certain leverage and coverage ratios, among others, that are not required by, or
presented in accordance with, IFRS. Our non-IFRS financial measures are defined by us as set out below.

We define “EBITDA” as net income/(net loss) for the period before income taxes, financial income, financial
expenses, depreciation, amortization and impairment losses and the reversal of impairment losses, each as shown
in the Consolidated Financial Statements.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA” as EBITDA adjusted for restructuring and reorganization costs, new store
opening, extension store/fulfillment center and improvement expenses, introduction/improvement of tools and
processes expenses and COVID-19 pandemic/geopolitical tensions related expenses.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue.

There is no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or
that similar items will not be incurred in the future.

We define “Capital Expenditure” as the sum of: (i) purchase of property, plant and equipment, (ii) purchase of
intangible assets and (iii) capitalized development costs each as shown in the consolidated statements of cash
flows in the Consolidated Financial Statements.

We define “Operating **Net Working Capital” as the sum of (i) inventories and prepayments for inventories,**
(ii) trade and other receivables, (iii) trade and other payables and (iv) others. ‘Others’ includes refund liabilities
and assets for the right to recover possession of goods for expected returns.

We define “Operating Free Cash Flow” as EBITDA plus the changes in net foreign exchange differences,
increase/decrease in other liabilities and provisions, decrease/increase in other assets, decrease/increase in trade
and other receivables, decrease/increase in inventories and similar assets, increase/decrease in trade payables and
other liabilities each as shown in net cash flows from operating activities (changes in current assets, non-current
financial assets, current and non-current liabilities presented in net cash flows from operating activities), minus
payment of lease liabilities as shown in net cash flows from financing activities and minus Capital Expenditure.

We define “Cash Conversion” as the ratio between Operating Free Cash Flow and Adjusted EBITDA.

For a reconciliation of our net income/net loss for the period to EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as well as a
reconciliation of Operating Free Cash Flow and Cash Conversion, see “Summary Consolidated Financial and
_Other Information.” For a reconciliation and description of Capital Expenditure and Operating Net Working_
Capital, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”

We present non-IFRS financial measures because we believe that they are widely used by certain investors,
securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. The
non-IFRS financial measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and
should not be considered in isolation or be used as a substitute for an analysis of our operating result as reported
under IFRS. There can be no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not
recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. Non-IFRS financial measures and ratios
are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to
net income/ net loss for the period or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any
other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or
financing activities. The non-IFRS financial measures may not give an accurate or complete picture of our
financial condition or results of operations for the periods presented and should not be relied upon when making
an investment decision. The non-IFRS financial measures have limitations as analytical tools. Some of these
limitations are:


-----

  - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual
commitments;

  - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

  - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest
or principal payments, on our debts;

  - although amortization, depreciation and write-downs are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated
and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and certain of these non-IFRS financial

  - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA reflect
cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made.

**SUMMARY**

**Overview**

We are a leading members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the off-price market with a
focus on mid-market to luxury fashion in Europe. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio
of around 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a
discreet and controlled channel and protecting their brand equity. With a heritage going back nearly 100 years,
we have evolved from an offline retail business to a tech-driven online platform. We offer a wide range of midmarket to luxury fashion brands at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80%, providing a permanent
assortment of approximately 250,000 items at any moment in time. Our online offering is available in multiple
languages and in 27 European countries. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we generated revenue of
€996.3 million, an Adjusted EBITDA of €131.4 million and an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.2%. Our online
revenue, which accounted for 91.7% of total revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, grew at a
CAGR of 41.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022.
While 70.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 was generated in Germany, our
international business outside of Germany continues to gain in importance relative to our Germany business and
experienced strong revenue growth of 86.3% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 (with a CAGR of 62.2%
from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022).

**Strengths**

We believe that our business is characterized by a number of key strengths that set it apart from our competitors:

**_Our business operates successfully in a large and resilient market with long-term growth supported by_**
**_structural tailwinds_**

We operate in the European online fashion market (excluding Russia and the United Kingdom) for mid-market to
luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season sectors. By
targeting the online off-price sector, we are well-positioned to take advantage of three structural long-term trends
in the fashion sector: (1) disproportional demand growth in the off-price market, expected to grow at 5% per year
from 2021-2025, (2) a shift to more premium fashion, with the mid-market to luxury fashion market expected to
grow at 4% per year from 2021-2025 and (3) rising online penetration in the European fashion market, expected
to grow at 9% per year from 2021-2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis).

The growing importance of sustainability for consumers and brands makes the off-price sector an increasingly
attractive choice for brands, as it allows for overstock, a structural phenomenon in the fashion industry, to be
monetized in a sustainable manner, at discounted prices to consumers and thus avoiding the destruction or disposal
of such overstock in landfills. Our closed-membership model offers brands the additional value of discreet
overstock clearing at scale and we believe it presents a unique business opportunity to build upon the growing
importance of sustainability.

As a result of the above factors, and as illustrated in the chart below, the online off-price sector amounted to
€44 billion in revenue across Europe (excluding the U.K. and Russia) in 2021, and is expected to grow at a CAGR
of 12% from 2021 to 2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis).

**_The most powerful flywheel in online fashion_**

The “flywheel” that drives our growth and profitability is the result of several strong elements that feed into one
another and that accelerate our viral engine. First, we develop strong brand relationships as a result of our closed
and discreet model that allows us to “silently” clear our brand partners’ overstock at scale. Second, based on our
strong brand relationships we are able to offer our members a current and attractive assortment of highly desirable
brands at discounts ranging from 20% to 80%. Third, we believe this in turn, leads to our members preferring to
shop with us, as reflected by exceptional customer key performance indicators (“KPIs”). In combination, these
three favorable elements lead to a continuous acceleration of our “viral engine” in which existing members make
use of their invitation rights to invite their families and friends. As a consequence, the “flywheel” has generated
low double-digit top line growth every year, thereby attracting new brand partners and reinforcing relationships
with existing brand partners. Our viral engine has contributed to an exponential growth engine as illustrated in the
chart below.

_Our brand partners_

Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model enables brands to discreetly clear large volumes of overstock
in a premium environment entirely separate from their full-price channels. Discretion is increasingly important to
brands, as overstock potentially threatens brand equity when sold openly, because the high degree of price
visibility in online shopping allows customers to view full-price and discounted offerings side-by-side.

We recently introduced a marketplace as part of our online platform to provide our brand partners the option to
market their products within our ecosystem without us having to hold these products in our own inventory. We
believe that the marketplace model will strengthen the relationship with our brand partners as it allows them to
increase their direct to customer (or “DTC”) revenue through our online platform while maintaining price control.
We offer brand partners to clear their overstock within a closed ecosystem. This also provides our brand partners
comfort that their merchandise is not being re-sold through the grey market (i.e., channels that our brand partners
have not authorized) or other channels that could harm their brand image. Thus, our discreet model protects their
brand equity and fosters our long-term and deep strategic partnerships leading to direct relationships with around
95% of all our brand partners, thereby avoiding intermediaries. Our model has also resulted in high brand partner
retention: we have retained all of our top 50 brand partners from 2017 (excluding intermediaries, private label
suppliers and suppliers who went out of business). These strong relationships allow us to offer attractive products
at desirable prices, which in turn, allow us to provide our brand partners with access to an affluent and loyal
customer base.

_Our products, prices and services_

Our superior brand proposition in turn leads to our ability to offer highly desirable products at attractive prices to
our customers and provide them with a service experience matching that of full-price online platforms. Our brand
proposition and the resulting strong relationships ensure that we are able to secure an attractive brand portfolio of
around 3,000 brands, comprising approximately 250,000 articles at any given time. Unlike almost all other online
platforms in the off-price segment, our offered assortment is broad and available permanently: we do not rely on
flash sales campaigns with long delivery times. Furthermore, our customers benefit from a fresh assortment: the
majority of our inventory has been listed on our online platform for less than six months. This desirable assortment
is complemented by attractive discounts of 20% to 80% on every single article and a fast delivery time of
approximately 3 days on average in 2021.

Our online platform is accessible to our customers through our highly rated app and website which offers a highend shopping and service experience on par with leading online full-price platforms, resulting in high customer
satisfaction and an excellent net promoter score (“NPS”) of approximately 60 at the end of 2021. As the fashion
market and its consumers increasingly make sustainability a driver of their purchasing decisions, we expect that
they will increasingly turn to us for their fashion needs, as our model allows customers a chance to shop fashion
in one of the most sustainable ways by giving them access to overstock and ensuring that every piece of fashion
that is produced is worn.

_Our customers_

Our desirable products, prices and service in turn attract a customer base that is active, loyal, and earns above
average disposable income. Driven by our broad offering and incentivized by our attractive loyalty scheme, our
customer base has been growing steadily. Our number of active customers was approximately 1.2 million,
1.5 million and 2.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021,
respectively, and 2.5 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, representing a CAGR of 38% between
2019 and 2021. Revenue by customer cohort, grouped by year, or customers who joined in a given year, typically
stays stable during the first year of membership. For example, online revenue from our active customers from the
years 2018, 2019 and 2020 changed in the respective subsequent years to 99% (2019), 96% (2020) and 118%
(2021). Our strong revenue retention track record is further illustrated by the following revenue by cohort chart:

We believe our value proposition caters to a highly attractive customer demographic, especially to affluent
consumers, which drives our strong revenue retention rate, that has increased from 100% to 118% in the period
between the year ended December 31, 2018 and the year ended December 31, 2021. Spend in the fashion industry
is heavily skewed toward the most affluent consumer demographic: in Germany for instance, 70% of total fashion
spending is made by 30% of the consumers (source: a leading international consultancy firm). These affluent
consumers spend more than €1,000 per year on fashion. The off-price market is inherently attractive to affluent
consumers. These consumers’ spend is approximately 2.5x more than the average consumer on fashion overall,
and 2.4x more in premium, 2.7x more in affordable luxury and 2.9x more in luxury, when compared to the market
average (source: a leading international consultancy firm).

_Viral engine_

Our “viral engine” is a self-reinforcing model in which existing members invite their friends, colleagues or other
acquaintances, thus creating multiple new customers. These new members then repeat the cycle, allowing a single
original customer to lead to substantial growth over time.

New “viral customers” are the primary drivers of our year-on-year structural revenue growth and an important
driver for our expansion. Our viral engine resulted in our online business revenue growing at a CAGR of 22%
from 2016 to 2020, after which time we introduced our paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter
of 2021. Moreover, the viral engine is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue
being spent annually to incentivize customers to invite other customers. The overall effect of this viral model is
substantial, with four new active customers generated by ten active customers in 2021.

**_Our proprietary technology platform supports our growing business_**

We are investing, on an ongoing basis, in building what we believe to be a world-class technology organization
to support our growing online platform. To provide for an engaging online storefront, we have designed attractive
websites and one of the best-rated online fashion apps (4.8* average app rating), which we regularly update to
match the high expectations of our customer base and the experience offered by full-price platforms. Our
customers enjoy access to a multi-device shopping experience from their mobile phones, tablets and desktop
computers that we believe allows for a convenient and frictionless shopping experience. Our technology supports
all major online and mobile platforms, including dedicated iOS and Android applications for both smartphones
and tablets. We program, develop and maintain our apps and website in-house, and we frequently update our
applications to offer new features.

Over the past few years, we have developed sophisticated IT systems which support our apps and websites,
customer service, supplier connectivity, communications and the monitoring of customer sales and improved
management of inventories. To support this effort, in addition to tech investments in our online platform, we have

4

built a tech driven value chain that integrates tech into our online and offline operations (including for our supply,
demand and onsite teams). To facilitate continued growth and build up our tech capacity in our operations, we are
expanding our tech hubs in Germany and Spain. A significant number of our FTEs relative to our overall business
are in tech-based roles (36% in tech, with tech and data headcount having grown more than 80% in 2021).

We believe that we operate a state-of-the-art cloud-based data infrastructure, which allows key business data to
be readily accessible across our business units to ensure faster, more data-driven decision making. Data analysts,
data scientists and data engineers are embedded across all business units, ensuring that the data we produce and
analyze is put to its best use. We have aimed to make technology and data a driver of each and every part of our
business by eschewing a dedicated IT department and instead embedding technology and data teams within all of
our business units.

**_Our operations are enabled for growth_**

To ensure customer satisfaction, we aim to make online off-price fashion shopping as convenient as with fullprice online players along the entire customer journey. From the initial browsing session to the customer receiving
their new products at their home, to providing any support that the customer may need along the way. This has
resulted in our online orders increasing by 29% and user sessions increasing by 37%, in each case, in the
three months ended March 31, 2022 as compared to the same period in 2021. Our browsing sessions generally
averages 7 minutes and 29 seconds per customer, with 84% of our browsing sessions in the three months ended
March 31, 2022 being mobile share.

Our operational platform includes (1) a highly developed content management system that quickly and efficiently
develops all our online content according to our content guidelines, (2) our extensive array of payment methods,
(3) our expansive logistics operation, with a modern fulfillment center in Poing, Germany and a second large
fulfillment center currently under development and (4) a highly trained customer service team that steps in
whenever a customer has a question or a problem – both pre- and post- order.

In 2021, we simultaneously improved and scaled our operational platform. We improved our on-time delivery
rate for our top customers, decreased the time-to-online for our merchandise and reduced the contact rate in
customer service, while shipping significantly more orders than in 2020.

**_Resilient business model with strong growth trajectory, adjusted EBITDA margins and high Cash Conversion_**

Our business has delivered a consistent track-record of highly profitable growth and Cash Conversion, strongly
outperforming the market. In 2021 we recorded revenue of €942.9 million, which represents an overall CAGR of
28.5% from 2019 to 2021 and again outperformed the wider fashion and our off-price market segment as

**Strategy**

To build on our existing success, we have identified the following key elements of our strategy:

**_Driving customer growth with paid customer acquisition_**

To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the
second quarter of 2021. Paid marketing efforts help us to invite potential new members who will act as new base
for future viral growth in underpenetrated regions where we want to grow the most. These new members will
drive our future viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral engine.
Paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer demographics and regions to drive our non-viral
growth in areas in which we have currently a low customer penetration (such as Northern Germany and
international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly favorable marketing efficiency ratio
(defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy divided by marketing spend) and has
maintained short payback periods while scaling marketing investment. Moreover, our paid marketing strategy is
closely aligned with our brand partners. As illustrated in the chart below, we have experienced strong profitability
as the roll-out of performance marketing continues.

As a result of these successful performance marketing efforts, we expect our viral engine to further accelerate and
continue to drive sustained growth while always focusing on maximum brand protection. See “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of_
_Operations—New customer acquisition” and “Our Business—Marketing—Paid customer acquisition._

**_Expanding our international footprint_**

We operate in the highly attractive and growing dedicated online off-price sector and discounted in-season and
end-of-season sector in Europe. Our international expansion has increasingly diversified our geographic revenue
streams, with the proportion of revenue derived outside our home market Germany steadily increasing in recent
years. In 2021, almost one-third of our revenue was generated in our international markets. Our unique proposition
provides us with the opportunity to continuously capture market share and participate in the structural growth
momentum of our market. We believe that we have developed a proven expansion strategy that will allow us to
expand into new international markets and increase penetration in our existing markets: (1) targeting and
prioritizing future growth markets, (2) localizing our offering for specific markets, (3) using performance
marketing campaigns to establish a customer base and (4) achieving viral customer acquisition that leads to selfreinforcing growth.

**_Establishing the leading European off-price marketplace_**

In 2021, we introduced a new marketplace model. Through our marketplace model, we offer our brand partners
to market their products on our BestSecret online platform without having BestSecret to hold these products as
own inventory. The marketplace model will allow our brand partners to increase their DTC revenue through our
online platform. We expect to achieve full scale operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022.
Through the expansion of our marketplace offering, we aim to expand our assortment through acquiring new
brand partners in the luxury segment and further grow the end of season fashion segment on BestSecret. We view
the marketplace as a unique growth opportunity. There are no existing online off-price marketplaces at scale in
the sector and we aim to become the number one fashion marketplace for off-price fashion in Europe. See
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting
_our Results of Operations—Marketplace.”_

**_Taking advantage of the consolidation trend_**

The dedicated online off-price sector in Germany, our core region, is expected to undergo significant consolidation
through 2025, when the top five market participants are expected to command 68% of the market. This
consolidation is predicted to be driven by brands reducing the number of their distribution partners, the increasing

8


-----

professionalization of the online space and economies of scale pushing out smaller participants (source: a leading
international consultancy firm). As a leading player in the dedicated online off-price market in Germany, Austria
and Switzerland, we are in a strong position to take advantage of the consolidation trend within the European
market. Our scale, our highly professionalized operations and our value proposition to clear overstock in a discrete
manner underline our advantageous position towards brands. With the aim of further benefitting from the
consolidation trend, we will continue to invest in increasingly scaling our business and advancing our offering.

**The Transactions**

We intend to use the gross proceeds from the Offering (i) to repay and redeem the Existing Notes and satisfy and
discharge the Existing Indenture on or about the Issue Date, and (ii) to pay certain fees and expenses in relation
to the Transactions. We also intend to enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility on or about the Issue Date.

We recorded preliminary revenue growth of approximately 20% for the six months ended June 30, 2022 compared
to €397.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021. This increase was achieved despite a high comparison
base, a challenging market environment characterized by reduced overstock availability and lower consumer
sentiment due to inflationary pressures. Compared to the pre-COVID period in the six months ended June 30,
2019 in which we recorded revenues of €244.4 million, we expect to have achieved a revenue CAGR of
approximately 25% in the six months ended June 30, 2022.

Our Adjusted EBITDA margin for the six months ended June 30, 2022 is anticipated to have followed the same
seasonality as the pre-COVID years of 2019 and earlier, when the Adjusted EBITDA margin in the six month
period was around two to three percentage points below that of the full year. This seasonality is typical for any
regular business year due to the volume and margin difference between the spring/summer and autumn/winter
seasons. The anticipated margin also reflects the increase of our paid customer acquisition activities during the
six months ended June 30, 2022, which represents one of the key pillars of our strategy to drive growth in
underpenetrated regions and markets.

**Our History**

BestSecret draws on a heritage of nearly 100 years in the textile industry. In 1924, Herman Schustermann founded
a textile company in Makredwitz, Germany and relocated to Munich in the late 1940s. In the early 1950s, Benno
Borenstein established his textile business in Munich. The two companies merged in 1960, and, after the death of
Herman Schustermann, a new cooperation was established with Herman’s son, Emil Schustermann, and Benno
Borenstein as partners. While Schustermann & Borenstein initially started out as a combination of two textile
trading companies with regional customer bases around Munich, ready-to-wear clothes were added to the portfolio
over the next decades and the closed membership retail business model was born.

Prior to 2007, our business operations were limited to our Schustermann & Borenstein offline retail stores in
Munich. In 2007, we launched our BestSecret online platform. In 2011, we made the BestSecret online platform
available in the Austrian market, setting the first milestone for our international expansion strategy. Since then,
we have continued our online expansion with the launch of our online presence in Sweden (2015), Switzerland
(2015), France (2016), The Netherlands (2018) and, most recently, Belgium (2021) and Poland (2022). Today,
our multi-language online platform is available across Europe with shipping available to 27 countries. We have
continued to maintain a limited physical presence with premium and outlet stores in strategic locations, with such
locations designed primarily to support our online platform.

In 2012, the BestSecret Group’s founding families sold a majority stake of 61% of the business to Ardian. In 2014,
construction commenced on the new centralized fulfillment center in Poing, Germany (near Munich), which
became operational in early 2016 and consolidated our then-existing seven warehouses. In 2014, we expanded
our offline retail footprint through the opening of a new store in Vienna, Austria. In 2016, we acquired Swiss
Online Shopping AG, a leading off-price player in Switzerland, to further expand our online presence in Germany,
Austria and Switzerland (hereafter referred to as the DACH region). In January 2017, funds owned and managed
by Permira acquired a majority stake in the Group. In 2019 and 2020, we expanded our fulfillment center in Poing,
Germany by approximately 60% to support our business growth.

In late 2020, Dr. Moritz Hahn joined us after nine years of experience at Zalando SE where he served as a member
of the Executive Committee and held numerous senior positions. He has since built a strong leadership team of ecommerce pioneers with decades of relevant experience across the tech and e-commerce industry, complemented
by senior individuals with long-term experience at and in-depth knowledge of the Company. In early 2021, this
senior leadership team announced the new vision “to become the number one online destination for off-price
fashion in Europe.” The accompanying strategy is focused on online pure-play, profitable growth across Europe.
The offline strategy was sharpened to focus on supporting our online value proposition with premium stores
designed to elevate our brand image and outlet stores to clear inventory that fails to sell online. In 2021, the
structure and brand profile across the Group was simplified and harmonized, merging and renaming the companies
to solely feature the BestSecret name across the Group.

**Principal Shareholder**

Permira is a global investment firm that backs successful businesses with growth ambitions. Founded in 1985, the
firm advises funds with total assets under management of more than €60 billion and makes long-term majority
and minority investments. The Permira Funds have made approximately 300 private equity investments in four
key sectors: technology, consumer, healthcare and services. Permira employs over 450 people in 16 offices across
Europe, North America, and Asia.

The Permira Funds have invested in various businesses in the DACH region, such as Engel & Völkers,
Neruaxpharm, P&I and TeamViewer. The Permira Funds also have extensive expertise in the premium and luxury
fashion space and in-depth knowledge of dealing with global brands, including Hugo Boss, Valentino, Golden
Goose and Dr. Martens.

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. In addition to the other information contained in this_
_offering memorandum, you should carefully consider the following risk factors before purchasing the Notes. The_
_risks and uncertainties we describe below are not the only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties of_
_which we are not aware or that we currently believe are immaterial may also adversely affect our business,_
_financial condition and results of operations. If any of the possible events described below were to occur, our_
_business, results of operations and financial condition could be materially and adversely affected. If that happens,_
_the trading prices of the Notes could decline, we may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Notes when_
_due and you could lose all or part of your investment. The order in which these risks are presented is not intended_
_to provide an indication of the likelihood of their occurrence or their severity or significance._

_This offering memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. See_
_“Forward-Looking Statements.” Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these_
_forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including, but not limited to, the risks described below_
_and elsewhere in this offering memorandum._

**Risks Related to Our Business and Industry**

**_Our business depends on our ability to continuously source and present a variety and quantity of attractive_**
**_products from various popular brands at attractive prices that will satisfy our customers’ preferences and_**
**_demands._**

The success of our business depends on our ability to continuously source attractive and high-quality merchandise
from a broad selection of high-quality brands at attractive prices and in a timely manner. If we are unable to
maintain our existing relationships or build new relationships with brands on favorable commercial terms, we may
be unable to offer an appropriate selection or quantity of merchandise at discounted prices, which would reduce
the appeal of our offering. Only a few of the brand partners we work with have a continuing obligation to provide
us with merchandise at historical levels or at all. Furthermore, building new relationships with prospective brand
partners can be a lengthy and time-consuming process leading to prolonged lead times until merchandise becomes
available for our members to purchase, which in turn could lead to a decrease in customer satisfaction.

Our business depends on successful merchandise financial planning and open-to-buy management (a management
system that aligns budgets to planned inventory). If these prove inadequate, we could fail to secure and offer an
attractive inventory to our customers, which could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of
operations.

We must also be able to present our offering to our customers by providing our customers with a unique and
personalized online fashion experience using machine learning algorithms and big data. If we are unable to present
our offering on our apps, websites and in our stores in an inspiring and attractive way or if we are unable to adapt
to the fast-changing developments of social media platforms, we may be unable to attract new customers, may
lose existing customers or may be faced with reduced volumes of purchases on our apps and websites, which
could limit our growth and prevent us from achieving or maintaining profitability. To deliver a desirable online
fashion experience to our customers, we rely on third parties and our brand partners to create content (including
photography, other media, and text) which we use on our online platform, in marketing campaigns, advertisements
and our online presence generally. Any failure by such third parties or brand partners to produce content that
effectively promotes our products could have an adverse effect on our business.

Our business also depends on sufficient availability of overstock in the market, which could be adversely affected
by supply chain disruptions, changes to the distribution plans of our brand partners or an overall decline in the
fashion market. For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine in late February 2022 has and will potentially
continue to have a wide range of supply chain implications, including increases in cost and disruption in freight
transport. Similarly, the lockdowns and the temporary port closures in China due to the COVID-19 pandemic have
and will potentially continue to lead to lower availability of stock because of reduced merchandise production or
transportation delays. See also “––Negative developments in global and local economic conditions in our markets
_could adversely impact consumer spending in the fashion market.” Additionally, our brand partners may not be_
willing or able to fulfill our product requests or fulfill our product request in full due to lack of stock, a change in
their supply-chain model or aggressive competition from other industry participants, including other off-price
retailers, on and offline, bidding against us for the same merchandise. Furthermore, brand partners may start
managing their product relationships with sellers on a global, rather than local level, which could adversely affect
us. As a result of our exclusive, invitation-only membership model, we must balance exclusivity and the protection

26


-----

of brand equity with our growth ambitions. If we fail to strike an appropriate balance, we could fail to achieve our
desired growth or negatively affect the brand equity of our brand partners, who may decide to prevent us from
offering merchandise for sale through a particular sales channel. Our ability to build a relevant offering for our
customers through a broad assortment of desirable products in the right categories and quantities could be affected
if we are prevented from offering merchandise through a particular sales channel.

If we are unable to secure an appropriate selection and quantity of merchandise on terms and conditions acceptable
to us, we may be unable to attract new customers and retain existing customers and consequently increase or
maintain sales, which could also diminish the attractiveness of our proposition for brand partners, limiting access
to merchandise, any one of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and
financial condition.

**_We face strong competition in our markets and such competition may intensify further._**

We are a leading European members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the market for
mid-market to luxury fashion. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio of approximately
3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a discreet and
controlled channel. The markets in which we operate are highly competitive. Our primary competitors are online
off-price and full-price retailers and platforms, including those devoted solely to fashion as well as other types of
online platforms and including single-brand as well as multi-brand retailers and marketplaces. In addition, we are
to some extent also competing with offline off-price and full-price retailers, such as traditional retail stores, brand
outlet stores and off-price fashion stores, due to the operation of our outlet locations and due to partially
overlapping customer demographics and supply markets. New competitors who enter our markets or existing
offline competitors that shift to online platforms may be successful in attracting customers, including our
customers, and thereby capturing market share from us, particularly in Germany, our core market. Some of our
current and potential future competitors may have greater financial, distribution, marketing, and other resources
than we do. Such competitors may be able to out-bid us for merchandise we would like to access, acquire more
attractive merchandise in greater quantities, deliver merchandise more rapidly, or devote more resources to
technology, order fulfillment and marketing than we can. The internet facilitates competitive entry and
comparison-shopping and renders e-commerce inherently more competitive than other retail platforms. In
addition, new and enhanced technologies, including search services, may favor our competition. Also, alternative
business models may emerge that would compete with us or diminish the attractiveness or utility of our business
model. In particular, social commerce, that is, the use of social networks in the context of e-commerce transactions,
as well as the growing popularity of online secondhand fashion retail, could potentially disrupt our business model.

If we are unable to compete effectively and fail to attract our target customers to purchase our merchandise, we
could lose market share to our competitors. In addition, our brand partners allocate merchandise among ourselves
and our competitors depending on the timeliness of orders. If we are unable to act quickly when our brand partners
make their merchandise available for purchase, or if we otherwise fail to procure merchandise from our brand
partners, for example, due to lack of availability in the market or if the brand partner decides to sell it to another
competitor in the market, we could lose market share to our competitors. Furthermore, our plans to expand our
business operations into new markets and markets in which we currently have a relatively small presence may be
adversely affected by strong competition. For example, some of our competitors may already have long
established customer or brand relationships and operations in these markets, which may put them at a competitive
advantage. We cannot be certain that we will be able to compete successfully. Should competitive pressure
intensify, the resources available to adjust our operations effectively and in a timely manner could be negatively
impacted, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

**_Consolidation in the online retail fashion industry could have a material adverse effect on our business,_**
**_financial condition, and results of operations._**

The online market for off-price mid-market to luxury fashion is undergoing rapid growth and substantial change,
which has resulted in increased competition and a consolidation trend. Acquisitions or other consolidating
transactions could harm us in a number of ways, including losing customers, revenue and market share, or forcing
our company to expend greater resources to meet new or additional competitive threats, all of which could harm
our operating results. Newly formed competitors and increased competition, threatening our market position or
copying our business model, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and
financial condition.

**_Negative developments in global and local economic conditions in our markets could adversely impact_**
**_consumer spending in the fashion market._**

We primarily sell fashion products online. Purchases of our customers are discretionary, and therefore dependent
upon the level of customer spending, particularly among affluent customers. As a result, our performance depends
on global and regional economic conditions, which have shown significant volatility in recent years. For example,
economic contraction, economic uncertainty, and the perception by our customers of weak or weakening
economic conditions, whether as a result of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 (“COVID-19”), the conflict in Ukraine
or otherwise, has and could continue to cause a decline in the demand for the merchandise we sell. In addition,
the continued prevalence of the COVID-19 pandemic, the conflict in Ukraine and their related effects has and
could continue to lead to a disruption of our supply chain or a decline in the supply of products produced by our
brand partners, which could in turn lead to supply shortages and inflationary pressure. The COVID-19 pandemic
has in the past led, and in the future could lead, to closure of our retail stores on a temporary or permanent basis.
If we are forced to close any of our retail stores, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic or for any other reason,
there is no guarantee that we would be able to terminate the relevant lease, secure a sublease or implement any
other cost-defraying arrangement for the remainder of the lease term. Furthermore, changes in discretionary
consumer spending may be influenced, among other things, by factors such as inflation, higher unemployment
levels, rising interest rates, reduced access to credit, recessionary economic cycles, increases in taxes or perceived
or actual declines in disposable consumer income and wealth.

Our online platform is available in multiple languages and offers shipping to 27 European countries, with the
majority of our revenue currently generated in our core market Germany and the DACH region. A negative
development, contraction or lack of growth in the economies of the DACH region or the other European countries
where we operate or may operate in the future, and in overall macroeconomic conditions, could materially
adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. We may be more affected by such
economic weakness or uncertainty than some of our competitors with more diversified international operations.
There is also a risk of increased taxes, for the purpose of addressing the extraordinary levels of public spending
and public debt related to the COVID-19 pandemic, in some or all of the European countries in which we sell our
merchandise. Tax increases that lead to increases in the sales prices of our products or the prices of services we
purchase or offer or reduce the income available for consumption could also weaken demand for our fashion
products.

Germany, our home market, which had seen a long period of stable economic growth since the financial crisis of
2007 - 2008, reported a 5.0% decline in its gross domestic product for 2020 compared to 2019 according to
Destatis. Although Germany’s gross domestic product reported a 2.7% increase for 2021 compared to 2020, the
ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and related countermeasures and the Russian invasion of Ukraine will likely
continue to dampen economic prospects in Europe in the short term. While Germany still generates most of our
revenue (72% in the year ended December 31, 2021), the international sales share has increased substantially in
recent years and international growth is one of our current strategic focus areas. Although the COVID-19
pandemic contributed to growth in the online fashion industry both in 2020 and 2021, an end to government
support programs, increased interest rates and the lifting of quantitative easing measures, could trigger a continued
economic downturn in one or more of our markets which may result in higher levels of unemployment and as a
consequence materially negatively affect consumer confidence and discretionary consumer spending, including
purchases of fashion and lifestyle products.

Geopolitical tensions, including but not limited to tensions between Russia and its neighboring countries,
including Ukraine, Poland and the Baltic states, tensions between China and the United States or acts of terrorism,
could also negatively affect the demand for and supply of our merchandise. In late February 2022, Russian military
forces launched a significant military action against Ukraine, which continues to date, and sustained conflict and
disruption in the region is likely. The instability of the general security situation, as well as any actions taken by
other countries, including new and stricter sanctions by the United Kingdom, the European Union, the U.S. and
other countries and organizations against officials, individuals, regions, and industries in Russia, Ukraine and
Belarus, and each country’s potential response to such sanctions, tensions, and military actions could have a
material adverse effect on our operations. Such instability could lead to delays in completing our planned
fulfillment center in Poland, as well as disruptions to the fulfillment center’s operations if such instability
continues after the fulfillment center is operational. We may also be affected due to the negative impact of such
geopolitical tensions on consumer confidence and consumer shopping behavior, resulting in lower sales and
results of operation.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the pace and extent of the global economic recovery remains highly
uncertain, and certain markets may not in the future achieve the growth rates that they have historically observed.

If our markets do not develop as anticipated or are negatively affected by global and local economic conditions,

**_Our industry and the sale of our products are subject to seasonal fluctuations and unfavorable weather._**

The industry in which we operate is seasonal in nature, and our revenue, profits, liquidity and inventory levels are
therefore subject to seasonal fluctuations. For example, we typically experience an increase in sales in the fourth
quarter of the year due to special sales events (e.g., Cyber Week) and the Christmas shopping season. In the year
ended December 31, 2021, revenue in the fourth quarter accounted for 34.2% of our total revenue for the year.
These seasonal influences have a direct impact on our results of operations and overall profitability. Any factors
that deter customers from purchasing online or visiting our stores during these periods could have a
disproportionate effect on our results of operations for the entire fiscal year.

In addition, atypical weather conditions could impact our sales and operating results. When the weather is warmer
than expected in the autumn and winter months, our customers tend to purchase fewer winter collection items.
Similarly, when the weather is cooler than expected in the summer months, our customers tend to purchase fewer
summer collection items.

During times of such unfavorable weather, we may be required to lower our prices, negatively impacting our
margins and our profit. If we cannot offset the lower-sales seasons with those having stronger sales, our business,
financial condition and results of operations may be adversely affected.

Seasonal fluctuations also impact our working capital, liquidity levels and inventory. We incur additional expenses
in the preparation for the increased demand we typically expect leading up to, and around, the special sales events
(e.g., Cyber Week sale) and Christmas season and other peak selling periods and must carry a significant amount
of inventory before such periods, which is also reflected in our liquidity. If too many customers access our website
within a short period of time due to increased demand or unexpectedly strong peaks, our businesses may
experience system interruptions that make our website unavailable or prevent us from efficiently fulfilling orders,
which may reduce the volume of goods we offer or sell and the attractiveness of our products and services. In
addition, we may be unable to adequately staff our fulfillment networks and customer service centers during these
peak periods and delivery and other third-party shipping (or carrier) companies may be unable to meet the seasonal
demand. In addition, seasonal products, such as winter clothing, being delayed may only be sold in the next season
and may increase storage costs.

Our quarterly results of operations may also fluctuate significantly as a result of a variety of other factors,
including but not limited to unfavorable weather, age and quantity of inventory at period end and the timing,
extent and impact of government-imposed restrictions related to COVID-19. As a result, historical period-toperiod comparisons of our results of operations are not necessarily indicative of future period-to-period results.
The results of a single fiscal quarter may not be an indication of our annual results or our future performance.

Increasing weather anomalies could complicate forecasting seasonal demand. Natural disasters, such as storms,
tornadoes, floods, earthquakes or other major weather disasters may also have a negative impact on our business.
Our inability to compensate for seasonal fluctuations and adapt to weather conditions may have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We operate apps, websites and other data systems through which we collect, maintain, transmit and store
information about our customers, brand partners and others, including credit card or other financial and personal
information, as well as other confidential and proprietary information. In addition, we gather and retain
information about our employees in the normal course of business. We also employ third-party service providers
that store, process and transmit proprietary, personal, and confidential information on our behalf. Furthermore,

we rely on a variety of security measures, including encryption and authentication technology licensed from third
parties in an effort to securely transmit confidential and sensitive information, including but not limited to credit

Any compromise or breach of our security measures, or those of our third-party service providers, could violate
applicable privacy and data security laws, including the General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) as well

**_We are exposed to the risk of security breaches, including cyber-attacks, and unauthorized use of one or more_**
**_of our websites, databases, online security systems or computerized logistics management systems._**

Like other online platforms, we are vulnerable to the risk of security breaches, including real or perceived
cyberattacks and unauthorized use of one or more of our websites, databases, online security systems or
computerized logistics management systems. While we take extensive steps to protect the security, integrity and
confidentiality of sensitive and confidential information (e.g., password policies and firewalls), our security
practices or those of our third-party service providers may be insufficient and third parties may breach our systems
(e.g., through Trojans, spyware, ransomware or other malware attacks, or breaches by our employees or third-party
service providers). Such attacks or breaches which may result in shutdowns of our sites, loss or corruption of data
or unauthorized use or disclosure of information. Such attacks might lead to blackmailing attempts, forcing us to
pay substantial amounts to release our captured data or resulting in the unauthorized release of such data, or to
identity theft or unauthorized purchases, requiring us to pay compensation to the victims. Cyberattacks could also
target our logistics, supply or office systems, which could result in order fulfillment delays, leading to cancelled
orders and a subsequent decline in revenue, as well as reputational damages. We have been subject to attempted
cyber, phishing or social engineering attacks in the past and may continue to be subject to such attacks in the
future. As we gain greater visibility, we may face a higher risk of being targeted by cyberattacks. We may also
need to devote significant resources to protect against security breaches or to address problems caused by
breaches, which may require us to divert resources from the growth and expansion of our business.

We and our third-party service providers may not have the resources or technical sophistication to anticipate or
prevent all such cyberattacks. Moreover, techniques used to obtain unauthorized access to systems change
frequently and may not be known until launched against us or our third-party service providers, and consequently
it may be impossible to properly secure our systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and
increased complexity of our IT infrastructure, as well as non-technical issues, including intentional or inadvertent
actions by our employees, our third-party service providers, or their personnel, could increase the likelihood of
security breaches. As we have significantly increased the number of employees working remotely due to the
COVID-19 pandemic, and as our businesses’ vendors and other business partners continue to work remotely as
well, our business and our partners may be more vulnerable to cyber-attacks. The techniques used to gain such
access to our business or our business partners’ information technology systems, our data, disable or degrade
service, or sabotage systems are constantly evolving, may be difficult to detect quickly, and often are not
recognized until launched against a target. Increasingly, unauthorized parties are exploiting access they gain to
third party vendors to target companies that do business with these vendors, and this may include third party
vendors with whom we do business.

Advances in computer capabilities, new technological discoveries or other developments have increased and could

infrastructure such as Microsoft Azure, which are critical to our business and inherently subject to various

electronic devices that are used by our customers. Our customers may also find our websites difficult to use or
may be unwilling to use our online platform for other reasons. In addition, our customers may lack confidence in

events or causes, could affect the security or availability of our apps and websites, prevent customers from
accessing our apps and websites and result in limited capacity, reduced demand, processing delays and loss of

grows and expands in scope. We are currently, among other projects, working on a new enterprise resource

**_Inability to forecast our business accurately could prevent us from properly planning expenses and process_**

We base our current and future expense levels on our forecasts of our business and estimates of future revenue.

timing and type of orders we receive, all of which are uncertain. Seasonal variations in our inventories, working
capital requirements and cash flows, among other things, also increase the difficulty of our financial forecasting
and could adversely affect our ability to accurately predict financial results. For any given season, a substantial
portion of our expenses is incurred in advance, and therefore fixed, due to the seasonality of demand for our
products and the necessity of purchasing merchandise with significant lead times. As a result, we may be unable

**_If we are unable to manage our inventory, or our online presence and store network in line with customer_**
**_demand, or if we are unable to otherwise forecast our business accurately, our sales levels and profitability_**
**_may decline._**

The off-price market for mid-market to luxury fashion is driven in part by fashion and beauty trends, and
consequently, the merchandise we sell is subject to changing consumer demands and preferences. Consumer
preferences regarding fashion design, quality, sustainability, and price tend to change rapidly. Hence, accurately
forecasting the selection and required quantities of such products in future periods is difficult. Accelerated through
short-term trends and sentiments on social media, the popularity of products can change significantly between the
time products are ordered and the date of sale. In addition, the lead times we must incur in taking delivery of
merchandise from many of our brand partners could pose challenges by increasing, in some cases significantly,
the time it takes us to respond to changes in product trends, consumer demand and market prices. Our success
depends in large part on our ability to gauge, react and adapt to changing consumer demands in a timely manner.

To be responsive to shifting customer tastes, we must manage our inventory levels closely, including through
identifying market trends and seasonality. If we misjudge, fail to identify, or fail to react swiftly to changes in
consumer preferences and market trends, our sales could decrease, and we could see a significant increase in our
inventory levels. If we are left with high levels of unsold or returned stock, or if our inventory provisions are
inadequate, our storage capacity could be negatively impacted and we could be required to mark down some of
our merchandise, which could lower our operating profits and have a significant negative impact on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Conversely, if we underestimate consumer interest in our merchandise, we may experience inventory shortages,
unfulfilled orders, increased distribution expenses and lower revenue and profitability than we could otherwise
have achieved. Inventory shortages could lead to customer dissatisfaction and adversely impact our reputation and
brand image.

The success of our buying teams is largely based on leveraging their decision-making, experience, and their
relationships with brand partners to outpace the competition. Insufficient controls within the purchasing process
may lead to unapproved or incorrect orders and may result in financial disadvantages for the Group due to
non-sellable inventory or liquidity risks.

In the fashion industry, customer demand can quickly change depending on many factors, including promotional
activities of competitors, rapidly changing tastes and preferences, frequent introductions of new products and
services, advances in technology and the internet and macroeconomic factors, many of which are beyond our
control, especially in light of the COVID-19 pandemic and the latest geopolitical developments and their impact
on economic conditions. With this constantly changing environment, our future business strategies, practices, and
results may not meet expectations or respond quickly enough to customer demand, and we may face operational
difficulties in adjusting to any changes, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations, financial condition, and prospects.

**_We depend on a reliable and efficient supply chain, which includes our fulfillment and returns centers,_**
**_transport service providers, third-party carriers that deliver merchandise to our online customers, and stores._**
**_Capacity constraints, interruptions or other failures in our supply chain could materially and adversely affect_**
**_our business, results of operations and financial condition._**

The profitability of our business depends on our ability to successfully process and deliver our customers’ orders.
Our ability to process and fill orders accurately and timely depends on the efficient, uninterrupted operation of
our main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany, where we store nearly all of our inventory, and our warehouse
management IT system. Our main fulfillment center is, therefore, critical to our business. If operations at our
fulfillment or returns centers were interrupted due to factors including, but not limited to, natural disasters (such
as flooding or fire), labor disruptions (such as labor strikes, shortages of temporary workers or ethical disputes),
technical defects, accidents, the COVID-19 pandemic, inappropriate storage of hazardous goods or any other
reason, it would have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position. In
addition, due to the high level of integration between our fulfillment center and points of sale, any interruption of
logistics at our fulfillment center would also have a significant adverse effect on our ability to supply our
customers and could result in customer dissatisfaction and harm to our reputation. A number of factors, many of
which are beyond our control, could disrupt the operation of our supply chain and jeopardize our ability to receive,
process and deliver our customers’ orders. System interruptions in any of our own or externally operated
technology platforms and services could delay or prevent our receipt of customer orders, shipments or returns.

expectations also depends on efficient internal processes as well as on third-party service providers to whom we
have outsourced certain processes, such as the handling of bulky goods or returns, and on third-party delivery
companies in each of the countries in which we operate. Any disruptions to these processes could also have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

We also rely on third-party service providers for the handling of certain processes and on a limited number of
third-party carriers, including DHL and Hermes, for the delivery of merchandise to our fulfillment and return

they experience performance problems, including as a result of inflationary pressures and the COVID-19
pandemic, it could negatively impact our customer experience. Any breakdown or disruption of the activities of
these service providers or carriers resulting from, among other things, inclement weather, natural disasters,
transportation interruptions, labor shortages, oil price increases, epidemics or unrest could impair our ability to
supply our fulfillment center at current cost levels or at all, make timely deliveries to customers or maintain an
appropriate logistics chain and level of inventory, all of which could adversely affect our reputation, business,
results of operations and financial condition. The merger, acquisition, insolvency or government regulation or
shutdown of any third-party contractors we use in our supply chain could also interrupt order processing, storage,
and delivery. Additionally, we may be unable to maintain relationships with our current carriers, and we may at
any point be required to contract with other carriers at a potentially greater cost. Finally, we may face price
increases by the third-party carriers we use which may result in higher fulfillment expenses we may only partially
be able to pass on to our customers.

Furthermore, we have incurred costs relating to our COVID-19 measures throughout our European offices, our
stores and our main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany. Such costs include bonus and hazard pay, increased
health and safety measures such as the temporary introduction of a third shift in our logistics center, the
implementation of regular tests and extensive hygienic measures, as well as costs relating to the closure of our
outlet in Frankfurt, Germany. Furthermore, the effects of the COVID-19 virus could in the future disrupt our
supply chain and distribution and fulfillment capabilities, including shipments of our merchandise to impacted
regions or from our main fulfillment center. There is continuing uncertainty around the breadth and duration of
business disruptions related to the COVID-19 pandemic including, but not limited to, store closures, as well as its
further impact on the global economy and consumer confidence. New variants of COVID-19 continue to emerge,
including the Delta variant and more recently, the Omicron variant, which have caused and may continue to cause
significant uncertainty. The future impact of other variants that may emerge cannot be predicted at this time and
could include temporary or permanent store closures. Such impacts may be affected by numerous factors,
including vaccination rates and availability, the effectiveness of current vaccines against the variants and
responses by various governments, such as lockdowns and other restrictive measures.

In addition, our ability to receive inbound inventory efficiently and ship merchandise to customers may be
negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and related response measures, inclement weather, fire, flood,
power loss, earthquakes, labor disputes, acts of war or terrorism, trade embargoes and similar factors. For example,
strikes at major international shipping ports may in the future impact our supply of inventory from our brand
partners, and the escalating trade disputes between the United States, the European Union, China, and certain
other regions could lead to increased tariffs on our goods. If the manufacturing, delivery, or supply chain
management processes relating to our merchandise are disrupted as a result of these factors or for any reason, we
may be delayed in restoring our inventory of the affected products and we may experience a significant increase
in our cost of sales. Any failure to adequately manage and improve our supply chain could reduce our transaction
volume, increase cancelled orders, undermine customer satisfaction, damage our business reputation, limit our
competitiveness, or otherwise materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial
condition, and prospects.

Our online platform is available in multiple languages and offers shipping to 27 European countries, with the
majority of our revenue currently generated in our core market Germany and the DACH region. As part of our
strategy, we are expanding internationally, which could lead to higher shipping and logistics costs that could
negatively impact our margins and could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations,
financial condition, and prospects.

In addition, our operations, including our supply chain, could be affected by the withdrawal of additional countries
from the EU. For example, we have operations in Poland, where we also expect an additional fulfillment center
to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023. A withdrawal of Poland from the EU would create significant

political and economic uncertainty regarding the future relationship between Poland and the EU and could cause
