**Overview**

We are a leading members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the off-price market with a
focus on mid-market to luxury fashion in Europe. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio
of around 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a
discreet and controlled channel and protecting their brand equity. With a heritage going back nearly 100 years,
we have evolved from an offline retail business to a tech-driven online platform. We offer a wide range of midmarket to luxury fashion brands at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80%, providing a permanent
assortment of approximately 250,000 items at any moment in time. Our online offering is available in multiple
languages and in 27 European countries. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we generated revenue of

78


-----

€996.3 million, an Adjusted EBITDA of €131.4 million and an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.2%. Our online
revenue, which accounted for 91.7% of total revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, grew at a
CAGR of 41.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022.
While 70.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 was generated in Germany, our
international business outside of Germany continues to gain in importance relative to our Germany business and
experienced strong revenue growth of 86.3% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 (with a CAGR of 62.2%
from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022).

**Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations**

Our results of operations and the operating metrics discussed in this section have been, and may continue to be,
affected by the key factors set forth below as well as certain historical and future events and actions. As many of
these factors are beyond our control and certain of these factors have historically been volatile, past performance
will not necessarily be indicative of future performance and it is difficult to predict future performance with any
degree of certainty. See “Risk Factors.” We consider the following factors to be the principal drivers of our results
of operations.

**_Growth of the European online fashion market and the off-price sector_**

Our target market is currently experiencing favorable structural trends. We operate in the European online fashion
market for mid-market to luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price sector. We have also expanded
into the discounted in-season and end-of-season sector. The overall European fashion market (excluding the U.K.
and Russia) amounted to €310 billion in revenue in the year ended December 31, 2021 based on analysis prepared
by a leading international consultancy firm and the Company. We operate in the dedicated online off-price sector
and discounted in-season and end-of-season sector, which amounted to €44 billion in revenue across Europe
(excluding the U.K. and Russia) in the year ended December 31, 2021 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 12%
from 2021 to 2025 based on analysis prepared by a leading international consultancy firm and the Company.

In recent years, we have transformed into a primarily online platform for off-price premium products. Revenue
from our online operations nearly doubled between the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2021
as a result of continued customer growth, strong international business development and an accelerated shift
towards e-commerce during the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of this growth, our online sales represented
93.0% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021, as compared to 77% of our revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2019. From January 1, 2019 to December 31, 2021, our number of active online customers
increased at a CAGR of 35%. We plan to maintain a limited physical presence of premium and outlet stores in
strategic locations designed primarily to support our online platform, with offline revenue expected to remain a
limited percentage of our total revenue.

In the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, governments across Europe imposed measures
that resulted in the temporary closure of stores as well as strict social distancing rules and hygiene regulations
between periods of closure. These closures had an adverse impact on our customer sales at offline stores, including
at our retail stores in Dresden, Munich, Dornach and Vienna. The German offline retail sector decreased by 30%
and 12% during the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, compared to the
previous year due to government-enforced store closures, the ongoing consumer shift away from offline platforms
to online platforms, and low frequency in customer store visits (Textilwirtschaft).

In contrast, the German online fashion retail sector increased by 21% and 16% in the years ended
December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, compared to the previous year. The European online
fashion market (excluding the U.K., Russia and Turkey) achieved revenue of €107 billion and €119 billion in the
year ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, which was an increase of 29% and 11%,
respectively, over the previous year (Statista).

While we believe that our business model is resilient to minor general economic effects, it is possible that
unfavorable macroeconomic events in Germany, and more broadly in Europe, may have a negative effect on the
growth of the European online fashion market and impact our customers and our results of operations. These
include factors that may affect consumer spending such as unemployment levels, inflation, wage rates, availability
of consumer credit and consumer confidence. For example, recent geopolitical tensions resulting from the Russian
invasion of Ukraine have destabilized the global economy and will potentially have a wide range of supply chain
implications, including increases in the costs of merchandise and disruption in freight transport.

79


-----

**_Our ability to secure an attractive variety and quantity of products_**

Our results of operations and profitability depend, to a considerable extent, on our ability to source and sell a
desirable and fresh mix of merchandise at attractive prices. We need to continuously source a variety and quantity
of merchandise from sought-after brands in a cost-effective manner. Our exclusive, invitation-only membership
model creates the opportunity for our suppliers to ensure that their overstock is sold in a discreet and controlled
environment, protecting their retail pricing strategies and the desirability of their brands while allowing them to
maximize value for their overstock. Our model allows us to clearly distinguish ourselves from other fashion
clearance channels such as online shopping clubs, factory outlet centers or other retail wholesalers has made us
an attractive and preferred partner and facilitates our early access to high-quality inventory at favorable prices.

Developments in the retail fashion industry, combined with the seasonal nature of our suppliers’ industry, may
impact the timing of our merchandise procurement and the prices at which we can procure such merchandise. For
example, favorable economic conditions in the fashion industry typically lead to increases in production volumes
by our suppliers and, consequently, may result in greater availability of overstock merchandise in the market and
an opportunity to source such excess overstock merchandise at better prices. In contrast, extended periods of
financial uncertainty or decreases in consumer spending may cause our suppliers to reduce their production,
thereby limiting the amount of merchandise on the market and negatively affecting the prices at which we can
purchase overstock merchandise.

Sufficient availability of overstock in the market can be adversely affected by supply chain disruptions, changes
to the distribution plans of our brand partners or an overall decline in the fashion market. For example, the Russian
invasion of Ukraine in late February 2022 has and will potentially continue to have a wide range of supply chain
implications, including increases in cost and disruption in freight transport. Similarly, the lockdowns and the
temporary port closures in China due to the COVID-19 pandemic have and will potentially continue to lead to
lower availability of overstock because merchandise is not able to be produced or is stuck in transit. See “Risk
_Factors—_ _Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Our business depends on our ability to continuously_
_source and present a variety and quantity of attractive products from various popular brands at attractive prices_
_that will satisfy our customers’ preferences and demands.”_

In addition, weather conditions can impact the timing and availability of merchandise. A mild autumn or a cold
spring may negatively impact the sale of winter and summer merchandise, respectively, by our suppliers. This
may lead to the earlier availability of merchandise but may also result in our need to lower prices to follow price
reductions by our suppliers online and in their high street retail locations. We have the ability to purchase large
quantities of merchandise, including mixed lots, which are lots that do not contain a typical distribution of sizes
and colors, increasing our value as counterparty to our suppliers. As a result, we are often the first choice of our
suppliers, reinforcing our customer proposition by giving us preferential access to desirable merchandise.

For the year ended December 31, 2020, our cost of sales was 53.1% of our revenue, due to measured price
reductions to support sales during market uncertainties resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, a lower
spring/summer merchandise level and a late onset of fall/winter season at the end of the three months ended
September 30, 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2021, cost of sales was higher, at 54.4% of our revenue,
due to the improved customer proposition with a larger and more attractive merchandise offering. For the three
months ended March 31, 2022, cost of sales was at 57.0% of our revenue, due to overall market conditions and
business growth as well as a shift to more premium and luxury brands, inflation, supply chain shortage and low
overstock availability.

**_Pricing_**

Our pricing strategy is to offer products to our customers at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80% of the
recommended retail price. Some of the various factors which influence our pricing strategy are beyond our control,
including market conditions, overstock availability, and demand. For example, inflationary pressure may impact
consumer purchasing power while geopolitical uncertainty and price volatility could lead to a decrease in
consumer confidence and spending.

Pricing of our products more broadly has a direct impact on our revenue and profitability margin. An effective
pricing strategy ensures optimal timing and pricing levels for a product as it moves through the different
markdown stages, thereby maximizing its revenue and profit contribution. Conversely, if we fail to manage our
pricing strategy adequately, we may lose sales and forfeit profitability. An effective markdown strategy improves
the quality of our inventory by ensuring efficient stock turnover. Continuous improvements of our pricing strategy
and our pricing-related technology, including a machine learning program for automatic pricing, have contributed

80


-----

to our revenue growth from the year ended December 31, 2019 to March 31, 2022 and, we believe, help us to
maintain healthy EBITDA margins even in challenging market conditions.

**_New customer acquisition_**

Our closed membership model and our loyalty program – the VIP Program – are designed to trigger invitations
(and therefore viral new customer acquisition) by rewarding customers for successfully inviting other members.
Our “viral engine” model, in which existing customers invite new customers, generates substantial topline growth
every year. New viral customers (customers who have been invited by existing customers) are the primary drivers
of our year-on-year structural revenue growth and an important driver for our expansion. Our online business has
grown at a CAGR of over 22% from the year ended December 31, 2016 to the year ended December 31, 2020.
Moreover, the viral engine is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue being spent
annually on viral engine-related expenses (e.g., commission vouchers).

To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the
second quarter of 2021. Our paid marketing efforts allow us to invite potential new members to join our closed
membership model so that they can drive viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members,
accelerating our viral engine. Our paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer demographics
and regions to drive our non-viral growth, especially in areas with currently low penetration (such as Northern
Germany and international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly favorable marketing
efficiency ratio (defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy divided by marketing
spend) and has maintained short payback periods while scaling marketing investment. As a result of our paid
marketing strategy, which has included a 2.0x increased marketing spend as a percentage of revenue in the three
months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2022, we experienced a
significant increase in the number of total new customers in the year ended December 31, 2021. The customer
base we gain from our paid marketing strategy is supported by subsequent viral growth in the customer base,
resulting in strong marketing efficiency with €6.40 in incremental revenue per €1.00 in marketing spend in the
year ended December 31, 2021. See “Our Business—Marketing—Paid customer acquisition.”

Our efficient marketing efforts allow us to scale our marketing significantly and maintain short payback periods:

(1) Payback period as period after first order of a new customer when CAC equals LTV. LTV (lifetime value) defined as cumulative PCII
per customer since first order. PCII defined as gross profit minus fulfillment, payment and customer care costs. CAC (customer
acquisition costs) defined as total marketing expenses divided by total number of new customers.

The expenses we incur for our viral customer growth model, such as commission vouchers earned by customers
for successfully inviting other members, are reflected as sales deductions within revenue. The expenses of
marketing activities, including our paid customer acquisition strategy, are included in our selling and distribution
expenses. In the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, we incurred
marketing expenses of €10.8 million, €9.4 million and €49.0 million, respectively.

**_Payment Options_**

A variety of payment options is an important aspect of the shopping experience for our customers. We offer
different payment methods tailored to meet our members’ payment preferences, both in our offline retail stores
and our online platform, including credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and pay-by-invoice

81


-----

(“buy-now-pay-later”). We are also focusing on making more local payments methods available to our
customers. Furthermore, we tailor our payment solutions by customer type and offer certain payment options,
such as pay-by-invoice, only to customers who have a sufficient purchase history with us.

Customers’ choices of payment method can have a significant effect on our profitability. For example, revenue
can vary by up to 2% based on the payment methods available in Germany. In addition, certain payment options
can have better order economics than others, for example through lower return rates. On an ongoing basis, we
plan to invest more into understanding the effects of payment options and encouraging our customers to choose
certain payment options over others.

**_Fulfillment_**

Our fulfillment expenses, which are included in the selling and distribution expenses, comprise, among others,
content creation, warehousing, handling and packaging, shipping costs, payment costs, customer service and
return costs. Our fulfillment expenses are driven by a number of factors, in particular the revenue share of our
online operations, the share of international shipping, the effectiveness of our fulfillment centers, capacity
utilization, as well as shipping and last-mile delivery costs for third-party carriers who handle the delivery of our
products.

We primarily incur fulfillment expenses when we ship online orders from our fulfillment center. In the years
ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, we incurred fulfillment expenses
(excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €88.3 million (15.5% of our revenue), €104.4 million
(17.0% of our revenue) and €162.3 million (17.2% of our revenue), respectively. The movement in our fulfillment
expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) to revenue)
in these periods was driven by the accelerated shift in our business towards online retail. Offline retail has a much
lower fulfillment expenses ratio than online and, consequently, the decrease in the revenue share of our offline
retail business has resulted in this structural increase in our fulfillment expenses ratio. Similarly, our shipping
costs have increased as a result of the growing share of our international business. This increase in fulfillment
expenses has been offset by positive impacts on our fulfillment expenses ratio from pandemic-related lower return
rates in the year ended December 31, 2020, and for the first six months of 2021, as well as increased shipping
efficiencies.

We expect growth in our business to lead to an increase in the complexity of our logistics and, as a result, higher
fulfillment expenses. For example, we expect an increase in our shipping costs per item as a result of the growing
international share of our business. We also expect an increase in fulfillment center costs due to continued reliance
on interim storage solutions first implemented during the six months ended December 31, 2021, and ramp-up
effects of our second fulfillment center in Poland, which we expect to enter preliminary stages of operation in
2023. We aim to partially offset these increases with targeted higher sales and the associated higher distribution
volume of our products, optimized fulfillment expenses per item from economies of scale, and volume discounts
despite price increases by some of our last-mile carriers. We expect that, combined with increased automation as
well as process optimization, the resulting offsetting effect will decrease our fulfillment expenses base per item.

Orders placed through our marketplace model, in which third-party brands sell their products through our
platform, are mainly fulfilled by third-party sellers. As we scale our marketplace offering, we expect to grow our
profitability margin as we receive revenue from marketplace sales while our fulfillment expenses with respect to
those sales remain flat.

**_Investments in infrastructure_**

Our result of operations and cash flows are influenced by our investments in technology and fulfillment center
infrastructure.

Our business depends significantly on our ability to process transactions on secure information systems and to
store, retrieve, process and manage information. In the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and
December 31, 2021, we invested €13.4 million, €10.5 million and €24.2 million, respectively, and in the three
months ended March 31, 2021 and March 31, 2022, we invested € 4.4 million and € 7.3 million, respectively, in
technology-related capital expenditures to strengthen our technological capabilities and in-house excellence. Our
primary front-office technology systems are used to market products to end customers, to manage, track and
deliver orders, and to monitor stock and interface with suppliers and other business relations. We have invested
significantly in the overall user-experience of our customer-facing systems, as well as in marketing and analytics
capabilities to boost customer acquisition, increase sales conversion, and manage churn. We updated our online

82


-----

platform to support multiple currencies and to be available in multiple languages. We also expanded the platform’s
payment capabilities to provide better and more flexible options for different customer needs. In addition, we
made investments in the scalability of the technology architecture across systems and processes, to support future
growth of the business and to manage orders more efficiently. We are also investing in a revamp of our technology
systems.

We operate a modern fulfillment center in Poing, Germany, near Munich. By investing €15.6 million and
€21.9 million in the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020, respectively, the facility was
expanded by approximately 60% to support our growing business. The extended site now has a footprint of 48,000
square meters and can hold up to 15 million items of inventory. The site also features multi-channel processes and
supplies our retail stores. We are in the process of launching our second fulfillment center in Poland, which we
expect to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023. We anticipate that once this new fulfillment center is fully
ramped up in 2024, it will approximately triple our current storage capacity at lower operating expense per item
than our existing network.

**_Returns_**

Allowing our customers to easily receive, try on, and if required, return products free of charge is an important
part of our value proposition to our customers, contributing to customer satisfaction, supporting customer
conversion (from browsing to purchasing) and increasing customer lifetime value. A number of factors influence
our return rates, such as products not matching their online description, issues with product quality, unexpected
variations in sizes, or wrong items being shipped. In the year ended December 31, 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic
also lowered our return rates, with a (temporary) shift in consumer focus to categories with structurally lower
return rates, such as casual wear or kids clothing. Return rates also marginally decreased likely due to customers
being less comfortable leaving their homes to return items. With the easing of pandemic-related restrictions and
customers growing accustomed to changed circumstances, return rates have trended back towards pre-pandemic
levels.

We continuously seek to optimize our return rates and minimize the costs associated with our free return policy
by focusing on the accuracy of our product descriptions, including size recommendations, and improving the
visualizations of our products on our apps and websites, avoiding returns where possible. For example, we are
developing technology which will enable us to further improve size recommendations. Furthermore, we focus on
providing an efficient and reliable fulfillment process to make sure the right items are shipped and arrive in a
timely fashion.

In accordance with IFRS, we use our historical return rates to anticipate future returns and to deduct such
anticipated returns from our revenue and cost of materials. If actual return rates turn out to be higher, we lose the
corresponding share of revenue and profits. Approximately 99% of the products returned are recorded as inventory
and are available for sale again having undergone a quality assessment to ensure the return products are in good
order. We provision in our accounts for the expected loss margin from returns and approximately 1% of return
products are damaged or otherwise not fit for sale.

**_Internationalization_**

We operate in the European online fashion market for mid-market to luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated
online off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season sectors, which currently present several highly
attractive market dynamics to participants. Our unique proposition provides us with the opportunity to
continuously capture market share and participate in the structural growth momentum of our market. Our strategy
for expansion into new international markets and to increase penetration in our existing markets is to: (1) identify
and prioritize future growth markets, (2) localize our offering for specific markets, (3) use performance marketing
campaigns to establish a customer base, and (4) achieve a viral status which in turn yields cyclical growth. We
have diversified our geographic revenue streams, with the proportion of our revenue derived from our
International segment steadily increasing, and amounting to 18.7%, 22.7% and 28.4% of our total revenue in the
years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, and 25.7% and 32.8%
in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and March 31, 2022, respectively. Our International segment revenue
experienced a CAGR of 58% between the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2021, compared to
a CAGR of 21% in our Germany segment revenue for the same period. The following chart demonstrates the
accelerated top line and strong earnings that have resulted from our internalization strategy on a quarter over
quarter basis.

83


-----

**_Marketplace_**

In addition to our core wholesale model through which we sell our own inventory of branded fashion merchandise
at attractive discounts, we introduced a new marketplace model in the year ended December 31, 2021. Through
our marketplace model, we offer third-party fashion brands the option to market their products on our BestSecret
online platform without holding these products in our own inventory. We expect to achieve full scale operation
of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022. We have already gained significant traction with our
marketplace offering, with customers placing an increasing number of orders on a monthly basis since its
inception.

The new marketplace is one of the core pillars of our growth strategy. Our marketplace model has helped us
expand into the market for discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion and we are well-positioned to provide
our customers with a wider product assortment, which we expect to drive incremental revenue. We also expect
the additional products to be from affordable luxury or luxury brands, who tend to prefer marketplace models that
give them more control over merchandise presentation and prices. The expanded product selection could
potentially contribute to an increase in order size and a reduction in the likelihood of products being out of stock,
as we attract more sellers who hold their own stock in existing product categories. We believe that these features
will further support our position as the go-to destination for online off-price fashion, increasing customer
satisfaction and loyalty.

Furthermore, we anticipate that the marketplace model will increase our profitability through commissions and
marketing fees with attractive economics, while having limited inventory and working capital impact. We expect
warehousing and fulfillment will typically remain in the hands of third-party suppliers. Our marketplace suppliers
are also able to rely on us for fulfillment at their option, which will allow us to benefit from incremental
commissions on third-party sales.

**_Seasonality_**

Our business is seasonal, which is typical for retailers in the fashion industry. For example, we typically experience
an increase in sales in the fourth quarter of the year due to several special sales events (e.g., Black Friday sale,
Cyber Week sale and the Christmas shopping season). In the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue in the fourth
quarter accounted for 34.2% of our total revenue for the year. In the three months ended December 31, 2020, and
December 31, 2021, we experienced exceptional revenue growth due to the structural shift towards online
shopping due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As the fashion market reaches an equilibrium between the online and
offline sectors, we expect our fourth quarter revenue to grow at a slower rate. As a result of our seasonality of
sales, any factors that harm our operating results during the fourth quarter of a year, including unfavorable
economic conditions or uncertainties caused by the COVID-19 pandemic affecting consumer spending levels or
inclement weather that deters customers from buying online or visiting our stores, could have a disproportionate
effect on our results of operations for the full year.

Our growth rate fluctuates from quarter to quarter, and we expect that it will continue to do so because of a variety
of factors, including the timing and success of our international marketing activities, the share of sales driven by
promotional activities, the launch of new categories and product types, seasonality and economic cycles that
influence retail apparel purchase trends.

Furthermore, our pricing is influenced by the seasonality of our industry and the impact of weather patterns and
conditions. For example, if a fall/winter season is unusually warm, we may fail to sell some of the merchandise
for the season, resulting in pricing pressure on the same merchandise in the following fall/winter season.

84


-----

In addition, our Operating Net Working Capital is affected by seasonal trading patterns. Our Operating Net
Working Capital typically reaches a peak from June to September, with a minimum position in January after the
Christmas season has passed.

**Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income**

Set forth below is a brief description of the key line items of our consolidated statement of comprehensive income:

**_Revenue_**

We generate our revenue primarily from the sale of fashion merchandise on our BestSecret online platform and
to a lesser extent from sales in our retail stores. Revenue is recognized upon delivery of the goods to the customer.
Revenue is recorded net of sales deductions, taxes and duties. For transactions with a statutory 14-day or longer
refund policy, the Issuer calculates the amount of the expected returns as of the reporting date based on historical
return rates under consideration of the actual returns until the date of preparing the consolidated financial
statements. We present the expected returns of goods on a gross basis and reduce revenue by the full number of
sales that are estimated to be returned. The sale of goods that is recorded in full upon delivery of the goods is then
corrected by the estimated number of returns. Commission vouchers earned by customers for successfully inviting
other members represent a payment to customers and therefore a revenue reduction when redeemed by the
customer. Revenue also includes revenue received from shipping fees charged to customers when merchandise is
purchased online, and commissions received from our marketplace sales. Revenue is recognized within our two
operating segments, Germany and International.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Our cost of sales comprises primarily cost of goods sold, expenses for inbound logistics, allowances on inventories
and other costs in connection with sales. Cost of goods sold equals expenses for goods sold less discounts and
rebates granted by suppliers. Expenses for inbound logistics include all expenses incurred before the inventories
are stored in the fulfillment centers and consist mainly of customs and incoming goods transport expenses.
Allowances of inventories reflect write-downs of inventories to the net realizable value to account for risks from
reduced demand or quality of the goods. Other cost of sales also covers cost for the storage of goods and expenses
for depreciation.

**_Selling and Distribution Expenses_**

Our selling and distribution expenses comprise marketing expenses, sales expenses and fulfillment expenses as
well as amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses. Sales expenses primarily include payment costs and
personnel expenses as well as incidental rental costs of the stores. Fulfillment expenses mainly consist of expenses
for outbound and return logistics including personnel costs associated with these processes, delivery costs and
deprecation.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Our administrative expenses comprise technology expenses and general administrative expenses. Administrative
expenses largely consist of personnel expenses. The non-personnel costs primarily contain depreciation, licenses
for software and maintenance fees as well as consultancy fees and sundry general administrative expenses.

**_Other Operating Income_**

Our other operating income mainly comprises compensations for damages, foreign exchange rate gains, rental
income from sublease and sundry other operating income. COVID-19 related lockdown revenue compensation is
also recognized in other operating income.

**_Other Operating Expenses_**

Other operating expenses mainly consist of bad debt losses, foreign exchange rate losses, expenses relating to
other periods and sundry other operating expenses.

**_Financial Income_**

Our financial income includes interest income on subleases, on tax refunds and sundry interest income.

85


-----

**_Financial Expenses_**

Our financial expenses primarily include interest expenses on the Existing Notes. Interest expenses on any
drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility as well as commitment fees related to the availability of
the Existing Revolving Credit Facility also are reported in this position as well as interest on lease liabilities and
interest expenses from the compounding of non-current provisions.

**_Income Taxes_**

Our income taxes comprise current income taxes and deferred taxes.

_Revenue_

Our revenue increased by €44.5 million, or 7.8%, from €571.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to
€615.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Revenue growth was driven by the structural shift towards
online shopping due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The increased online business was offset by a decrease in
revenue from offline (brick-and-mortar) business at our premium stores and our outlet stores of 33% mainly due
to the government-imposed COVID-19-related temporary store closures in spring and winter 2020.

_Cost of sales_

Our cost of sales increased by €31.1 million, or 10.5%, from €296.0 million for the year ended December 31,
2019 to €327.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due to overall business
growth and to targeted online marketing campaigns following the outbreak of COVID-19. Cost of sales as a
percentage of revenue were 53.1% for the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to 51.8% for the year
ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to our targeted online campaigns in spring 2020 that
used discounts and vouchers with the deliberate aim of maintaining top-line growth and generating cash, a lower
spring/summer merchandise level due to a customer shift to prudent buying during the COVID-19 pandemic, as
well as a late onset of fall/winter season in the year ended December 31, 2020. Depreciation of property, plant
and equipment and amortization of intangible assets of €0.9 million (2019: €1.0 million) and personnel expenses
of €3.8 million (2019: €3.1 million) are reported in cost of sales for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Selling and distribution expenses_

Our selling and distribution expenses increased by €63.1 million, or 32.6%, from €193.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, to €256.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was mainly due to
impairment losses on goodwill, higher business volume resulting in higher shipping and payment service provider
costs as well as an increase in health and safety measures, such as the introduction of a third shift in our fulfillment
center. For the reasons described above, selling and distribution expenses as a percentage of revenue increased
from 33.9% for the year ended December 31, 2019 to 41.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020.

For the year ended December 31, 2020, our selling and distribution expenses consisted of fulfillment expenses
(excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €104.4 million (2019: €88.3 million), marketing expenses
of €9.4 million (2019: €10.8 million), sales expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of
€27.5 million (2019: €33.0 million) and amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses of €115.2 million
(2019: €61.3 million). The fulfilment expenses increased by €16.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2020
compared to the year ended December 31, 2019 which was mainly due to higher business volume resulting in
higher shipping costs as well as health and safety measures, such as the introduction of a third shift in our
fulfillment center. As a result, the fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses (excluding
amortization and depreciation expenses) to revenue) came to 17.0% in the year ended December 31, 2020
(2019: 15.5%). In the year ended December 31, 2020, marketing expenses equaled 1.5% (2019: 1.9%) of our
revenue. The decrease in marketing expenses was mainly due to a range of cost-cutting measures. Compared to

the year ended December 31, 2019, sales expenses decreased by €5.5 million in the year ended December 31,
2020. This decrease was mainly attributable to a decrease of personnel expenses for the stores in the amount of
€6.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 due to receipt of government grants for short-term workers in
our stores in Germany and Austria during COVID-19. This effect was partly offset by an increase of payment
costs in the amount of €1.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 due to higher business volume. In the
year ended December 31, 2020, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible
assets as well as impairment of goodwill and intangible assets, amortization and impairment of purchase price
allocation assets increased to €115.2 million (2019: €61.3 million), and primarily comprised impairment of
goodwill in the amount of €50.8 million (2019: nil) and amortization of brand names and customer base of
€47.5 million (2019: €47.5 million). The impairment losses on goodwill related to our stationary retail stores due
to the accelerated shift towards online shopping caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

December 31, 2019 to €61.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase of administrative
expenses was primarily driven by higher personnel expenses, costs incurred for IT licenses and maintenance, costs
relating to COVID-19 and health and safety as well as higher consultancy fees. In the year ended December 31,
2020, our administrative expenses consist of technology expenses of €12.3 million (2019: €10.4 million), general
and administrative expenses of €41.1 million (2019: €37.1 million) and depreciation of property, plant and

December 31, 2020, depreciation, amortization and impairment expenses contain impairment losses of
€2.8 million on software no longer used.

Our other operating expenses decreased by €0.7 million from €3.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019

_Income taxes_

Our income taxes changed by €1.2 million from €0.2 million tax expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019
to €1.0 million tax income for the year ended December 31, 2020. This development is primarily due to increased

“Schustermann & Borenstein” as a result of our rebranding, as well as changes in the valuation of goods.

_Net income/(net loss) for the year_

Our loss for the period amounted to €53.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the net
income of €3.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a decrease of €57.5 million. The
decrease was primarily due to impairment of goodwill and intangible assets in the amount of €50.8 million
(2019: nil) related to our offline retail stores due to the accelerated shift towards online shopping caused mainly
by the COVID-19 pandemic. One-time expenses in connection with COVID-19, restructuring measures, as well
as a lower gross margin, also contributed to the decline in earnings.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our main sources of liquidity are our net cash flows from operating activities and long-term financing, including
the Notes and the New Revolving Credit Facility.

Our business model is focused on ensuring adequate liquidity to allow for flexibility with regard to the purchase
of merchandise, including opportunistic mixed lot purchases. Given our positive liquidity situation, we are able
to procure merchandise through our operating cash generation, providing us with flexibility which we believe
particularly appeals to our suppliers.

Our ability to generate cash from our operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn
dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors,
many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the section titled “Risk Factors.”

Although we believe that our expected net cash flows from operating activities, together with the borrowings that
will be available under the Notes and New Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated
liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient net cash flows
from operating activities or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us
to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs. See “Risk Factors—Risks
_Related to our Financial Profile—We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to service our indebtedness and_
_may be forced to take other actions to meet our obligations under our indebtedness, which may not be successful.”_

**Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures on Risk**

We are exposed to a number of risks arising from our normal business activities.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risk is the risk that the fair value or the future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because
of changes in market prices. Market risk comprises three types of risk: interest rate risk, currency risk and other
price risk, such as equity price risk.

Based on the position as of December 31, 2021, there is no sensitivity of equity.

_Interest Rate Risk_

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because
of changes in market interest rates. As of December 31, 2021, there are no financial instruments affected by
floating interest rates. We do not enter into interest rate derivatives.

**_Credit risk and risk concentration_**

Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligations under a financial instrument or customer
contract, leading to a financial loss.

We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities (primarily trade and other receivables) and from our
financing activities, including deposits with banks and financial institutions.

Due to the introduction of non-recourse factoring, there is no significant exposure to credit risk from transactions
with customers.

There were no significant credit risks or concentration of risk arising from the delivery of goods to major
customers as of December 31, 2021. We do not hold collateral as security.

_Financial instruments and cash deposits_

Credit risk from balances with banks and financial institutions is managed by our treasury department in
accordance with our Group policy. Investments of surplus funds are made only with approved counterparties and
within credit limits assigned to each counterparty. The limits are set to minimize the concentration of risks and
therefore mitigate financial loss through a counterparty’s potential failure to make payments.

**Liquidity risk**

We provide sufficient liquidity for each individual entity by cash pooling. Our objective is to maintain a balance
between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of bank overdrafts and bank loans. As of
December 31, 2021, roughly 10% (December 31, 2020: 10%) of the undiscounted cash outflows from financial
liabilities are due in less than one year. We assessed the concentration of risk with respect to refinancing our debt
and concluded it to be low. We have access to a sufficient variety of sources of funding, and debt maturing within
12 months can be rolled over with existing lenders. We have access to a short-term loan of €110.0 million. We
expect the New Revolving Credit Facility to be undrawn as of the Issue Date.
