**Significant Accounting Policies**

In preparing our Consolidated Financial Statements, assumptions and estimates have been made which affect the
amounts and presentation of the assets and liabilities recognized in the statement of financial position, income and
expenses, and contingent liabilities. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could result in outcomes
that may require a material adjustment to the carrying amount of our assets and liabilities in future periods.

By “significant,” we mean that the following accounting policies are both important to the portrayal of our
financial condition and results and require management’s subjective judgments, often as a result of the need to
estimate the effects of matters that are inherently uncertain. You should note that the preparation of our financial
statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities,
disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements and the reported amounts of
revenue and expenses during each reporting period.

All assumptions and estimates are made according to the best of our management’s knowledge and belief in order
to present a true and fair view of our net assets, financial position and results of operations. Since the actual values
may, in individual cases, differ from the assumptions and estimates that were made, these are continuously
reviewed. Adjustments to the estimates that are relevant for the financial statements are made in the period in
which the change occurs, provided that the change relates only to this period. If the change relates not only to the
reporting period but also to subsequent periods, the change is taken into account both in the period of the change
and in subsequent periods.

**_Use of estimates and assumptions_**

The preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements in conformity with IFRS requires management to make
judgements, assumptions and estimates that have effects on the amounts carried and the related disclosures.
Although these estimates are based on the current events and measures to the best of management’s knowledge,
there may be deviations between estimated and actual results. Significant estimates and assumptions have been
used for the following matters in particular:

  - Impairment of non-financial assets (including forecasts and COVID-19 impact)

  - Determination and assessment of the realizability of deferred tax assets on unused tax losses and income
taxes

  - The determination of provisions for restoration expenses and other provisions

  - Assumptions for the calculation of returns and unredeemed coupons

  - Inventory valuation

  - Segment reporting

  - Assessment of the necessity and amount of allowances on receivables

  - Interest rate in connection with IFRS 16

  - Assumptions with regard to making use of termination or extension options in connection with IFRS 16

  - Assumptions with regard to useful life of our customer base due to the structural shift towards
e-commerce

These key forward-looking assumptions and estimates, which involve a significant risk of changing the carrying
amounts of assets and liabilities within the next fiscal year, are discussed below.

_Impairment of non-financial assets (including forecasts and COVID-19 impact)_

All non-financial assets that fall within the scope of IAS 36 are tested for impairment if there are indicators that
the asset may be impaired. Regardless of indicators of impairment, goodwill acquired in business combinations is
tested for impairment once a year at the level of the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs.

100


-----

This assessment implies significant judgment and estimates, in particular in light of the uncertainties in connection
with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic precipitated the shift to the online market
business in general, and this was taken into account in the impairment testing for goodwill and the review of useful
lives for the intangible assets recognized using the purchase method in compliance with IFRS 3. Impairment exists
when the carrying value of an asset or cash-generating unit exceeds its recoverable amount. This is the higher of
its fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use. The recoverable amount is sensitive to the discount rate
used for the DCF model that is the basis for the calculation of the fair value less costs of disposal used as well as
the expected future cash flows and the growth rate used for extrapolation purposes. These estimates are most
relevant to goodwill. The key assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount for the goodwill, including
a sensitivity analysis, are disclosed and further explained in Note 5.1 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements / Note 5.2 of the 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and 2019 Audited Consolidated
Financial Statements.

_Assessment of realizability of deferred tax assets on unused tax losses and income taxes_

Uncertainties exist with respect to the interpretation of complex tax regulations and the amount and timing of
future taxable income. Different interpretations of tax laws may result in additional tax payments for prior years.
Various factors such as past experience with tax field audits and different treatment of tax regulations by tax
authorities are considered.

Deferred tax assets are recognized to the extent that it is probable that they will be recovered, which is dependent
on the generation of sufficient future taxable profit. Assumptions about the generation of future taxable profits
depend on management’s estimates of future cash flows. These judgments and estimates are subject to risks and
uncertainty. Consequently, there is a possibility that changes in circumstances will alter expectations, which may
impact the amount of deferred tax assets recognized at the reporting date. In such circumstances, some or all of
the carrying amount of recognized deferred tax assets and liabilities may require adjustment, resulting in a
corresponding credit or charge to the income statement.

_Determination of provisions for restorations expenses and other provisions_

The determination of provisions for restoration expenses requires assumptions and estimates regarding the
discount rates, expected costs and timing of these costs. If the interest effect resulting from the discounting is
significant, provisions are discounted at a pre-tax interest rate that reflects the risks specific to the liability.

Provisions mainly comprise provisions for restoration expenses and provisions for restructuring. Whether a
present obligation is probable or not requires judgment. The nature and type of risks for these provisions differ,
and management’s judgment is applied regarding the nature and extent of obligations in deciding if an outflow of
resources is probable or not.

As of December 31, 2021, long-term provisions were discounted at an interest rate of 7.5%. In the case of
discounting, timing-related interest effects are recognized as financial expenses.

_Calculation of returns and unredeemed gift vouchers_

_Returns_

For transactions with a statutory 14-day or longer refund policy, we calculate the amount of the expected returns
as of the reporting date based on historical return rates under consideration of the actual returns until the date of
preparing the Consolidated Financial Statements, which are taken into account in order to reduce revenue. As of
December 31, 2021, deferred sales recognized as refund liability amounted to €39.7 million compared to
€19.6 million as of March 31, 2022. The right to recover possession of expected returns is reported under other
current non-financial assets.

_Unredeemed gift vouchers_

The acquiring customer has a claim from the sale of vouchers for fulfillment up to a period of three years. If
vouchers sold are not redeemed within this period, we realize the revenue from the voucher sale. Liabilities from
the sale of gift vouchers are recognized under other liabilities and amounted as of December 31, 2021, to
€2.0 million compared to €1.7 million as of March 31, 2022.

101


-----

_Inventory valuation_

Inventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. Net realizable value is the estimated selling
price in the ordinary course of business less the estimated necessary costs to make the sale. Estimates are necessary
to determine the sales proceeds that can be achieved in the normal course of business.

_Segment reporting_

IFRS 8 requires that operating segments be defined on the basis of the internal reports of corporate divisions that
are regularly reviewed by our chief operating decision maker (the “CODM”) for the purpose of making decisions
about the allocation of resources and assessing the financial performance of the respective segments. Before the
year ended December 31, 2021, we have reported in two segments: “Online” and “Stationary retail business”. In
recent years, we have been able to leverage the accelerated structural shift to e-commerce and set a clear focus on
online business. This transition has resulted in a change in the internal organizational setup, the management
structure, and the internal reporting lines. As the internal organizational and management structure and the internal
reports submitted to the CODM form the basis for determining our segment reporting format, we have therefore
realigned our segment reporting. For the year ended December 31, 2021 and thereafter, our segments will be
“Germany” and “International”. Primary emphasis is placed on the key performance indicators revenue and
adjusted EBITDA.

_Assessment of the necessity and amount of allowances on receivables_

The determination of the necessity and amount of valuation allowances on receivables requires assumptions and
estimates regarding the credit risk and underlying time intervals. In the case of a return debit, we inform the
customer and defines a period for payment. When the defined time period has elapsed, written warnings are sent
to the customers.

We use a provision matrix to calculate expected credit losses for receivables. The provision rates are based on
days past due and our historical default rates. The default rates are evaluated based on expectations as to the
collectability of the receivables.

_Interest rate in connection with IFRS 16_

The interest rate in connection with IFRS 16 was determined considering our debt structure and the useful life of
the leased assets. To measure lease liabilities, we use the incremental borrowing rate. We estimate the incremental
borrowing rate by using observable input factors.

_Assumptions with regard to making use of termination or extension options in connection with IFRS 16_

The lease term of an asset is determined by considering options to terminate or extend the lease that are reasonably
certain to be exercised. The possibility of the use of termination or extension options is appreciated by considering
the overall business development as well as the term of existing leases.

_Assumptions with regard to useful life of the Group’s customer base_

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the structural shift towards e-commerce. Our testing of the useful
lives of the Group’s customer base at the end of 2020 resulted in the for prospective adjustment of the remaining
useful life of the “Schustermann & Borenstein” customer base from 10 years to 5 years starting in the 2021
reporting period onwards. This change in estimate of useful life has resulted in an increase of the annual
amortization of €6.6 million.

**_Business combinations and goodwill_**

Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method according to IFRS 3. The cost of an
acquisition is measured as the aggregate of the consideration transferred measured at acquisition date fair value
and the amount of any non-controlling interests in the acquiree. For each business combination, we elect whether
to measure the non-controlling interests in the acquiree at fair value or at the proportionate share of the acquiree’s
identifiable net assets. Acquisition-related costs are expensed as incurred and included in administrative expenses.

When we acquire a business, we assess the financial assets and liabilities assumed for appropriate classification
and designation in accordance with the contractual terms, economic circumstances and pertinent conditions as at
the acquisition date.

102


-----

Goodwill is initially measured at cost, being the excess of the aggregate of the consideration transferred and the
amount recognized for non-controlling interests over the net identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed.

After initial recognition, goodwill is measured at cost less any accumulated impairment losses. For the purpose of
impairment testing, goodwill acquired in a business combination is, from the acquisition date, allocated to each
of our cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from the combination, irrespective of whether other assets
or liabilities of the acquiree are assigned to those units. In case of any structural changes of the respective cashgenerating units within the Group, an impairment review and potential reallocation of the goodwill according to
IAS 36 is performed.

As of March 31, 2022, our goodwill amounted to €203.5 million. No impairment was recognized in the three
months ended March 31, 2022.

**_Fair value measurement_**

We apply measurement techniques that are appropriate under the respective circumstances and for which
sufficient data is available for fair value measurement. In the process, observable market inputs are to be preferred
to non-observable inputs.

Assets and liabilities measured or presented at fair value in the Consolidated Financial Statements are classified
on the basis of the following fair value hierarchy. The classification uses the input parameters of the lowest
category that is material to the fair value measurement.

  - Level 1: Quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities

  - Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the assets or
liabilities, either directly or indirectly

  - Level 3: Unobservable inputs for the assets and liabilities

**_Revenue recognition_**

Revenue is recognized according to IFRS 15 at an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity
expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring goods to customers, net of taxes and duties, and taking into
account agreed payment terms. Revenue is reported net of discounts, rebates, taxes and returns. Since we have
price discretion in our sales transactions and also bear the inventory and credit risk, we generally act as a principal
and are therefore the principal party of all sales transactions. In addition, we purchase some products such as
jewelry on a commission basis. In this case, we are acting as an agent, but are free in the setting of prices. Revenue
is recognized net of commissions earned.

Revenue recognition requires the fulfillment of the following recognition criteria:

_Sale of goods and products_

Our contracts with customers for the sale of merchandise generally include a single performance obligation. We
have concluded that revenue from the sale of merchandise should be recognized at the point in time when control
of the asset is transferred to the customer. In the stationary retail business, revenue is therefore recognized upon
handing over the goods and in online trading upon delivery of the goods to the customer.

_Accounting treatment of returns in the online business_

Under IFRS 15, the consideration received from the customer is variable because the contract allows the customer
to return the products. We use the expected value method to estimate the merchandise that will be returned because
this method predicts most accurately the amount of variable consideration to which we will be entitled. We apply
the requirements in IFRS 15 on constraining estimates of variable consideration such as return rate to determine
the amount of variable consideration that can be included in the transaction price. We present a refund liability
(other current financial liabilities) and an asset (other current non-financial assets) for the right to recover
possession of goods from a customer separately in the statement of financial position, taking into account the costs
incurred for processing the return and the losses resulting from disposing of these goods. We present the expected
returns of goods on a gross basis in the statement of comprehensive income and reduce revenue by the full amount
of sales that we estimate to be returned. The dispatch of goods that is recorded in full when they are shipped is

103


-----

then corrected by the estimated value of the returns. Generally, we allow goods to be returned within a period of
14 days of receipt. Longer periods may be agreed upon contractually.

_Friends recommend friends – loyalty program_

We maintain a recommendation program for customers. Every time the invitee (recommended customer) places
an order, the inviting customer (inviter) receives a one-time commission voucher of 10% to 20% (2020: 10%).
The inviter also receives a 5% to 7% (2020: 5%) voucher based on the total purchases of the invitee within a
period of 12 months. According to IFRS 15, both vouchers represent a payment to customers and therefore a
revenue reduction when redeemed by the customer.

**_Taxes_**

_Current income taxes_

Current income tax assets and liabilities are measured at the amount expected to be recovered from or paid to the
tax authorities. The tax rates and tax laws used to compute the amount are those that are enacted or substantively
enacted at the reporting date in the countries where the Group operates and generates taxable income.

For the purpose of measuring current German taxes, a uniform corporate income tax rate of 15% is applied to
distributed and retained earnings and a solidarity surcharge rate of 5.5% is applied to that amount. That yields a
tax rate of 15.825%. In addition, German trade tax is imposed on profits earned in Germany. The trade tax is based
on the assessment rates of the various municipalities and the basic federal rate, which has been a flat rate of 3.5%
according to Sec. 11 (2) GewStG (Gewerbesteuergesetz: German Trade Tax Act) since the corporate tax reform
in 2008. The trade tax varies depending on the different assessment rates of the municipalities, but a flat rate of
11.41% for the year ended December 31, 2021, 11.62% for the year ended December 31, 2020 and 11.70% for
the year ended December 31, 2019 is applied in our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

The profits earned by the non-German Group companies are calculated on the basis of the national tax laws
applicable in each country and taxed at the tax rates in effect in those countries. The country-specific tax rates
range from 21 to 25%. Our tax rate is 27.23%. Current tax expenses are calculated on the basis of the taxable
income for the year. Taxable income differs from the net income/profit presented in the consolidated statement of
comprehensive income as a result of the expenses and income that will not be taxable or that becomes tax-exempt
in later years. Our liability for current taxes is calculated on the basis of the tax rates enacted or substantively
enacted in the near future.

_Deferred taxes_

Deferred taxes are provided using the liability method on temporary differences between the tax bases of assets
and liabilities and their carrying amounts for financial reporting purposes at the reporting date.

Deferred tax liabilities are recognized for all taxable temporary differences, except:

  - Where the deferred tax liability arises from the initial recognition of goodwill or of an asset or liability
in a transaction that is not a business combination and, at the time of the transaction, affects neither the
accounting profit nor taxable profit or loss; and

  - In respect of taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries, associates and
interests in joint ventures, where the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences can be controlled
and it is probable that the temporary differences will not reverse in the foreseeable future.

Deferred income tax assets are recognized for all deductible temporary differences, carry-forward of unused tax
credits and unused tax losses, to the extent that it is probable that taxable profit will be available against which
the deductible temporary differences, and the carry-forward of unused tax credits and unused tax losses can be
utilized except:

  - Where the deferred income tax asset relating to the deductible temporary difference arises from the initial
recognition of an asset or liability in a transaction that is not a business combination and, at the time of
the transaction, affects neither the pre-tax accounting profit nor taxable profit or loss; and

  - In respect of deductible temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries, associates and
interests in joint ventures, deferred tax assets are recognized only to the extent that it is probable that the

104


-----

temporary differences will reverse in the foreseeable future and taxable profit will be available against
which the temporary differences can be utilized.

The carrying amount of deferred income tax assets is reviewed at the end of each reporting period and reduced to
the extent that it is no longer probable that sufficient taxable profit will be available to allow all or part of the
deferred income tax asset to be utilized. Unrecognized deferred income tax assets are reassessed at the end of each
reporting period and are recognized to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profit will allow
the deferred tax asset to be recovered.

Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply to the year when
the asset is realized or the liability is settled, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted at the end
of the reporting period.

Deferred income tax relating to items recognized in other comprehensive income or directly in equity is recognized
in other comprehensive income or directly in equity and not in the profit or loss.

Deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities are offset if a legally enforceable right exists to set off current tax
assets against current tax liabilities and the deferred taxes relate to the same taxable entity and the same taxation
authority.

Tax benefits acquired as part of a business combination, but not satisfying the criteria for separate recognition at
that date, are recognized subsequently if new information about facts and circumstances change. The adjustment
is either treated as a reduction in goodwill (as long as it does not exceed goodwill) if it was incurred during the
measurement period or recognized in profit or loss.

As of March 31, 2022, deferred tax liabilities amounted to €74.1 million (compared to €76.3 million as of
December 31, 2021) and mainly belongs to the acquired intangible assets in connection with the purchase price
allocation (trademark and customer relationship) and the valuation of inventories. The deferred tax liabilities
decreased due to the amortization of the PPA assets.

_Value added tax_

Revenue, expenses, assets and liabilities are recognized net of the amount of value added tax (“VAT”) except:

  - If VAT incurred on a purchase of assets or services is not recoverable from the taxation authority, in
which case VAT is recognized as part of the cost of acquisition of the asset or as part of expense item as
applicable; and

  - Where receivables, payables and finance lease liabilities are stated with the amount of VAT included.

The net amount of VAT recoverable from, or payable to, the taxation authority is included as part of receivables
or payables in the consolidated statement of financial position.

**_Intangible assets_**

Intangible assets acquired in the context of a business combination under IFRS 3 are recognized separately from
goodwill and measured at fair value at the acquisition date. This includes customer bases and brand names. These
are recognized as an intangible asset according to IAS 38, measured at fair value and amortized over their expected
useful lives.

An intangible asset is derecognized upon disposal or when no further economic benefits are expected from its use
or disposal. Any gain or loss arising on derecognition of the asset (calculated as the difference between the net
disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset) is included in the statement of comprehensive income
when the asset is derecognized.

Intangible assets which are not acquired as part of a business combination but as purchased licenses are initially
recognized at cost.

Intangible assets with a finite useful life are amortized on a straight-line basis over their economic useful life.
Intangible assets with finite useful lives are reviewed for possible impairment if there are indications of
impairment at the reporting date. The remaining useful life and the amortization method for intangible assets with
a finite useful life are reviewed at least at the end of a reporting period. If the reasons for impairment have been

105


-----

eliminated, a reversal to a maximum of the historical cost is set as the upper limit. Required changes in the
amortization period and method are treated as changes in estimates. Impairment losses on intangible assets, e.g.,
customer base and brand names, with finite useful lives are included in amortization within selling expenses.

As of March 31, 2022, intangible assets (mainly customer relationships and trademarks) amounted to
€275.0 million.

The main intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis and pro rata temporis over their customary useful
lives: the brands Schustermann & Borenstein (useful life: 5 years) and BestSecret (useful life: 20 years) and the
Schustermann & Borenstein customer base (useful life: 8 years) and BestSecret customer base (useful life:
8 years).

Other intangible assets (software and licenses) are recognized at acquisition cost less amortization charged pro
_rata temporis using the straight-line method (useful life of between 3 and 8 years)._

Due to the rebranding of the Group in 2019, the total useful life for the brand name Schustermann & Borenstein
was reduced from 30 years to 5 years as of January 1, 2019. At the same time, the total useful life of the customer
base Schustermann & Borenstein was reduced from 20 years to 14 years. Reviewing the useful lives at the end of
2021 showed the need for prospective alignment of the remaining useful life of the respective customer bases to
3 years from the 2022 reporting period onwards. This reduces the total useful life for the Schustermann &
Borenstein customer base accordingly to 8 years.

In the case of internally generated intangible assets, IAS 38 makes a distinction between the research phase and
the development phase. Costs incurred during the research phase cannot be capitalized; instead they must be
recognized as an expense. On the other hand, costs incurred during the development phase must be capitalized,
_provided that the reporting entity demonstrably fulfills all six criteria set out in IAS 38.57 et seq. The Group_
primarily develops key components of software (Best Secret website and the Best Secret app as well as expenses
for the Group’s other IT-systems and infrastructure) used by the Group. A useful life of 4 to 5 years is assumed
for development activities in connection with the software.

**_Property, plant and equipment_**

Property, plant and equipment are recognized at cost and depreciated in accordance with their expected useful life
using the straight-line method. The Group treats changes in the residual values or useful lives that arise during use
as a change in estimates. Depreciation is charged over the following useful lives: 6–20 years for leasehold
improvements, 5–14 years for plant and machinery and 5–23 years for furniture and fixtures.

An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognized upon disposal or when no further economic benefits are
expected from its use or disposal. Any gain or loss arising on derecognition of the asset (calculated as the
difference between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset) is included in the statement of
comprehensive income when the asset is derecognized.

The residual values, useful lives, and methods of depreciation of property, plant and equipment are reviewed at
the end of each reporting period and adjusted prospectively, if appropriate. If the carrying amount of a tangible
asset exceeds the recoverable amount, an impairment loss is recognized, in addition to systematic depreciation, in
order to lower the carrying amount to the recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair
value less costs to sell (net selling price) and the present value of the net cash flows expected to result from the
continued use of the asset. Whenever possible, the net selling price is derived from the most recently observed
market transactions.

As of March 31, 2022, property, plant and equipment amounted to €75.6 million.

**_Inventories_**

Merchandise accounted for as inventories is recognized at cost pursuant to IAS 2. Cost is calculated on the basis
of an item-by-item measurement, factoring in the additions from the point of view of the sourcing market or on
the basis of the moving average price of the goods. Incidental acquisition costs are generally measured on a
monthly basis. Supplier payments that are to be classified as a reduction of cost reduce the carrying amount of
inventories. Consumption of inventories is recognized within the costs of sales in the statement of comprehensive
income.

106


-----

Merchandise as of the reporting date is measured at the lower of cost or net realizable value. The net realizable
value is the expected selling price less the costs necessary to make the sale. Adequate write-downs to net realizable
value were made to allow for all risks from slow-moving goods and/or reduced salability. When the circumstances
that previously caused merchandise to be written down below cost no longer exist, the write-down is reversed.
Our inventories as of December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021 were €160.2 million,
€155.7 million and €232.9 million, respectively, and €248.2 million as of March 31, 2022.

**_Cash and cash equivalents_**

Cash and cash equivalents are measured at amortized cost. The “Cash and cash equivalents” item in the
consolidated statement of financial position previously comprised cash, bank balances and credit balances with
Payment Service Providers with a banking license (cash in transit). In the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements, the Group reclassified credit balances with Payment Service Providers not holding a banking license
from ‘cash and cash equivalents’ (cash in transit) to ‘trade and other receivables’. The prior year figures as of
December 31, 2019 and as of December 31, 2020 included in the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements
have been adjusted accordingly. The cash in transit balances are presented as cash equivalents as these balances
are immediately credited to the bank account with the payment service providers over which the company has
direct power of disposal.

For the purpose of the statement of cash flows, the cash and cash equivalents defined above are presented less
overdraft facilities that have been drawn, as these are an integral part of the Group’s available cash.

**_Leases_**

_The Group as a lessee_

We lease various properties, equipment and vehicles. Leases are typically entered into for periods of 2 to 22 years.
Lease terms are negotiated on an individual basis and contain a wide range of different terms and conditions. The
lease agreements do not impose any covenants, but leased assets may not be used as security for borrowing
purposes.

Leases are recognized as a right-of-use asset and a corresponding liability at the date on which the leased asset is
available for use by the Group. Each lease payment is broken down into an interest component and a principal
repayment. Interest is recognized in the income statement over the lease period so as to produce a constant periodic
rate of interest on the remaining balance of the liability for the reporting period (effective interest method). It is
remeasured when there is a change in future lease payments arising from a change in an index or rate, if there is
a change in the Group’s estimate of the amount expected to be payable under a residual value guarantee, if the
Group changes its assessment of whether it will exercise a purchase, extension or termination option or if there is
a revised in-substance fixed lease payment. The right-of-use asset is depreciated on a straight-line basis over the
shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term. When the lease liability is remeasured in this way, a
corresponding adjustment is made to the carrying amount of the right-of-use asset, or is recorded in profit or loss
if the carrying amount of the right-of-use asset has been reduced to zero.

Assets and liabilities arising from a lease are initially measured on a present value basis. Lease liabilities include
the net present value of the following lease payments:

  - fixed payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentives receivable

  - renewal options

  - variable lease payments that are based on an index or an (interest) rate

  - amounts expected to be payable by the lessee under residual value guarantees

  - the exercise price of a purchase option if the lessee is reasonably certain to exercise that option, and

  - payments of penalties for terminating the lease, if the lease term reflects the lessee exercising that option.

The lease payments are discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease, if that rate can be readily
determined. If that rate cannot be readily determined, the lessee uses the Group’s incremental borrowing rate.

Right-of-use assets are measured at cost comprising the following:

107


-----

  - the amount of the initial measurement of the lease liability

  - any lease payments made at or before the commencement date

  - any initial direct costs, and

  - restoration costs.

Payments associated with short-term leases (lease term of 12 months or less) and leases of low-value assets are
recognized on a straight-line basis as an expense in profit or loss.

_The Group as a lessor_

We sub-lease office and retail space.

When we act as a lessor, we determine at lease inception whether the lease is a finance lease or an operating lease.
To classify each lease, we make an overall assessment of whether the lease transfers substantially all of the risks
and rewards incidental to ownership of the underlying asset. If this is the case, then the lease is a finance lease; if
not, then it is an operating lease. As part of this assessment, we consider certain indicators such as whether the
lease is for the major part of the economic life of the asset.

In case of finance leases, rental income is recognized using the effective interest method over the term of the
subleases and reported under interest income. Payments received from operating subleases are recognized within
other operating income.

**_Trade and other receivables_**

The “Trade and other receivables” item in the statement of financial position comprises balances with payment
service providers not holding a banking license and receivables against customers.

Trade receivables are initially recognized at the settlement-date fair value and subsequently measured at amortized
cost, which is usually the original invoice value less a loss allowance for expected impairment losses. The loss
allowance for trade receivables is determined based on lifetime expected credit losses, which are calculated as the
present value of expected cash shortfalls. Changes are recognized as other operating expenses in the consolidated
statement of comprehensive income.

For its online customers, the Group offers the option to purchase on account. In connection with this payment
option, the Group works with a factoring provider, transferring substantially all risks and rewards resulting from
the receivables to the factoring company and derecognizing receivables in the statement of financial position.

**_Financial liabilities_**

Financial liabilities are recognized when a Group company is a contractual party to a financial instrument on the
settlement date. Financial liabilities are recognized initially at fair value, net of transaction costs incurred.
Financial liabilities are subsequently measured at amortized cost. Any difference between the proceeds (net of
transaction costs) and the redemption value is recognized in the consolidated income statement over the duration
of the obligation using the effective interest rate method. The effective interest method is used to calculate the
amortized cost of a financial liability and to allocate interest expenses to the respective periods. The effective
interest rate is the interest rate that is necessary to discount the estimated future cash outflows, including all fees
and remuneration paid and received that are an integral component of the effective interest rate, transaction costs
and other premiums or discounts, through the expected life of the financial instrument, or a shorter period to equal
the net carrying amount upon initial recognition.

The embedded prepayment option for the Existing Notes is considered to be closely related to the host contract
according to IFRS 9. We define “closely related” up to a 5% difference between amortized cost and redemption
price as of the redemption date.

Other financial liabilities, for instance loans accepted, trade and other payables and other liabilities, are measured
at amortized cost. Trade and other payables are amounts owed as consideration for goods or services provided to
us in the normal course of business including amounts owed to a payment service provider governing the
settlement of supplier liabilities. In the normal business cycle, all liabilities are due in one year or less and are

108


-----

therefore classified as current; otherwise, they are presented as non-current liabilities. For current liabilities, that
means they are measured at their repayment or settlement amount, while non-current liabilities and long-term
debts are measured at amortized cost in accordance with the effective interest method. Non-interest-bearing or
low-interest-bearing financial liabilities are measured at their settlement value or nominal value.

We derecognize a financial liability when the related obligation has been paid, canceled, or has expired. The
difference between the carrying amount of the derecognized financial liability written off and the consideration
received or due is recognized in the statement of comprehensive income.

**_Provisions_**

Provisions are recognized in accordance with IAS 37 when the Group has a present obligation (legal or
constructive) as a result of a past event, it is probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits
will be required to settle the obligation, and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation.

A best estimate is made of the amount of the provisions, taking into consideration all the discernible risks arising
from the obligation. This refers to the amount that is most likely needed to settle the liability. Provisions with a
residual term of more than one year are discounted on the reporting date.

_Provisions for restoration obligations_

The Group recognizes provisions for restoration obligations for leasehold improvements in the leased warehouses
and office buildings. The provision is recognized at an amount equivalent to the present value of the estimated
future restoration obligations. The restoration obligations are recognized as part of the cost of the leasehold
improvements at the corresponding amount. The estimated cash flows are discounted using a discount rate that is
commensurate to the maturity and risk profile. The unwinding of the discount is expensed as incurred and
recognized as an interest expense in the statement of comprehensive income.

_Provisions for restructuring measures_

Provisions for restructuring measures are recognized to the extent that decisions by management have been
announced in sufficient detail to those affected as of the reporting date. The definition of a restructuring measure
includes for example basic reorganization with significant effects on the focus of business activities.

**INDUSTRY**

**_Markets_**

We are a leading European members-only destination for online off-price fashion, with a focus on mid-market to
luxury fashion. We currently provide customers in 27 European markets with exclusive access to a portfolio of
approximately 3,000 brands ranging from mid-market to premium to luxury. We are the market leader in the
dedicated off-price market in Germany holding a market share of approximately 16% for the year ended
December 31, 2020 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). Since 2011, we have
continued to expand our international footprint and today target a market opportunity of €44 billion in annual
consumer spending in the markets and categories which we address (source: a leading international consultancy
firm, Company Analysis). For the fiscal year ended December 31, 2021, we had revenue of €943 million of which
72% of revenue was generated in Germany and 28% was generated in our international markets.

We operate in the online off-price fashion market, which comprises of dedicated off-price players like BestSecret
as well as the in-season and end-of-season discounts, which are primarily served by brands directly and full-price
retailers.

We are positioning our business to take advantage of further market opportunities, which includes a better
penetration of the discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion segment. We anticipate that our marketplace
model, whereby third-party brands sell directly to customers using the BestSecret online platform, will enable us
to expand our access to these previously underserved market segment as well as expand our luxury brands offer.

**_The Online Off-Price Mid-Market to Luxury Fashion Market_**

_Demand_

We operate in a sizeable and growing sub-segment of the larger European fashion market. The total European
fashion market (excluding the U.K. and Russia) amounted to approximately €446 billion in 2021, of which the
mid-market to luxury fashion segment accounted for approximately €310 billion (source: a leading international
consultancy firm, Company Analysis). For the same period, the off-price segment, which incorporates both
dedicated off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion, amounted to approximately €128 billion,
with the online segment thereof accounting for approximately €44 billion (source: a leading international
consultancy firm, Company Analysis). This market has grown at a CAGR of 15% from 2015 to 2021 and is
estimated to grow at a CAGR of 12% to reach €69 billion by 2025 (source: a leading international consultancy
firm, Company Analysis).

The European online, off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market can be further broken down into the
dedicated off-price segment and the discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion segment. The former relates
to items sold through brand outlets and specialized off-price retailers while the latter refers to discounted fashion
that is sold at full-price retailers, for example in end-of-season sales campaigns. The dedicated online off-price
segment has grown at a CAGR of 15% since 2015 and accounted for approximately €14 billion of the total €44
billion European online, off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market in 2021 (source: a leading international
consultancy firm). The online discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion segment accounted for the
remaining €30 billion. (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). By 2025, the
dedicated online off-price segment is expected to account for approximately €22 billion of the total expected €69
billion European online, off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market. The online discounted in-season and endof-season fashion segment accounted for the remainder, which is expected to grow to €47 billion by 2025. (source:
a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis).

(1) European online, off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion supply market.
Source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis.

_Supply_

The market growth in the European online, off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market is supported by an
increasing supply of overstock. The fashion ecosystem is structurally predisposed to create overstock. Most brands
have highly complex and broad product assortments comprising several thousand stock keeping units. Therefore,
it is very difficult to accurately forecast demand, particularly across every single product. This holds true despite
more data-driven demand planning. Long lead times, quickly changing fashion trends and unpredictable weather
patterns are additional obstacles in accurately forecasting demand, which can result in significantly increased days
of inventory outstanding when forecasts exceed actual sales. Furthermore, it is in brands’ interests to have
ambitious growth targets, especially given the disadvantage from overproduction is very limited. Overproduction
is economically usually the preferred strategy given the production of higher volumes typically offsets any margin
impact. Brands are thus incentivized to overproduce and avoid the risk of stock outs, missing expectations or
customer dissatisfaction. Furthermore, brands are moving away from their historical approach of destroying or
exporting overstock given their increased focus on ESG related matters with regards to their positioning with
stakeholders. This requires brands to increasingly partner with off-price players to handle their overstock.

Available supply in the European online, dedicated off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market exceeds the
demand by approximately 1.5x, and this supply is expected to grow by between 13-16% per year until 2025
(source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). Given the demand growth in the European
online, dedicated off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market is expected to be approximately 13% over the
same period, this 1.5x multiplier is likely to increase.

111


-----

The COVID-19 pandemic had a mixed impact on the available supply of overstock for the off-price market.
During the first waves in early 2020, retail closures and reduced consumer sentiment led to a decline in fashion
demand. This unexpected hit to brands and retailers subsequently led to large amounts of additional overstock
flowing into the off-price market. Rising supply chain issues during the second half of 2021 led to brands keeping
more stock in house as a buffer, which led to a reduction in available overstock in the off-price market.

**_Key Trends_**

Best Secret’s core market segment lies at the intersection of three megatrends, which are expected to lead
continuous and sustainable double-digit growth rates in this core market.

_Shift to More Premium Fashion_

The European mid-market to luxury fashion market (excluding the UK and Russia) is expected to grow at a CAGR
of 4% between 2021 and 2025 reaching a market size of approximately €362 billion in 2025 (source: a leading
international consultancy firm). Although this market contracted slightly from 2015 to 2021, its projected rebound
driven by shifting consumer preferences with an increasing focus on quality and moving away from the fast
fashion industry. This is further supported by increased consumer propensity and willingness to spend more on
fashion. Moreover, management believes that Gen Y&Z consumers are increasingly motivated to wear branded
fashion, driven by the increasing prevalence of social media, which supports their inclination to shift spending
towards premium brands.

_Disproportional Growth in Off-Price_

The European off-price mid-market to luxury fashion market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 4% between 2021
and 2025. This translates into an increase in online off-price penetration in the European mid-market to luxury
fashion market from 41% as of 2021 to 43% by 2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company
Analysis).

Demand for off-price is increasing due to the growing discount habits of consumers and the increased accessibility
of off-price channels both online and offline. Off-price penetration in the midmarket to luxury fashion market has
grown from 8% in 2015 to 11% in 2021 and is projected to reach 12% by 2025 (source: a leading international
consultancy firm, Company Analysis). Consumers are increasingly conscious about “value for money” but remain
highly brand focused which provides strong tailwinds for the off-price channel.

Growth in the off-price channel is also being fueled by steady over-supply. Fashion and luxury brands invest a
large number of resources into building and protecting their brand equity. In the event of overstock, which is a
structural phenomenon in the fashion industry, many fashion and luxury brands have historically turned to the
destruction or exportation of overstock to protect their brand equity and price integrity. With increasing concerns
over sustainability in the fashion industry and the promotion of a circular economy, this is no longer a viable
option for brands. The off-price channel provides an alternative solution and attempts to ensure that every piece
of clothing that is produced can be matched with an owner and is ultimately worn. This helps brands to clear their
overstock in a more sustainable way and creates an additional revenue stream.

_Rising Online Penetration in Fashion_

The fashion market is still in a relatively early stage of its transition from offline to online. The European online
fashion market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6% between 2021 and 2025. This translates into an increase in
online penetration in the European fashion market from 24% as of 2021 to 30% by 2025 (source: a leading
international consultancy firm, Company Analysis).

Online penetration in the off-price market is rapidly growing as consumers increasingly prefer to shop online in
this market segment. Online penetration of the European off-price, mid-market to luxury fashion market has grown
from 24% in 2015 to 38% in 2021 and is projected to reach 44% by 2025 (source: a leading international
consultancy firm, Company Analysis). This is driven by the rise of the digital native Gen Y&Z population as well
as the greater convenience of shopping online, which is particularly relevant in off-price where offline outlets tend
to be located at distance from city centers. Online penetration is also being positively impacted by the increasing
availability of online platforms, offering more choice to the consumer. Online off-price penetration varies by
country with countries at different stages of the adoption curve. The U.K. leads with the highest penetration in
Europe and long-term penetration rates are expected to converge across countries in the long-term, indicating
further upside potential and runway for growth across Europe.

112


-----

During 2020 and 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic led to an accelerated shift from offline to online due to the
various COVID-19 related restrictions on offline businesses and this online shift is expected to persist in a post
COVID-19 world.

**Competition**

The market for online off-price fashion is experiencing a consolidation trend, especially in Germany, where the
top 5 players are estimated to hold a market share of approximately 47% as of December 2020. There are several
structural reasons for this ongoing consolidation trend. Brands are looking to reduce the number of distribution
partners they work with to reduce complexity and increase efficiency with respect to their distribution. We believe
we are well positioned to capitalize on this trend given our ability to clear large quantities of overstock as well as
our development of trusted, long-standing relationships with our brand partners. Further, the online channel is
becoming increasingly professionalized and is also exposed to large economies of scale, thus providing further
support for consolidation of the market.

The competitors we face differ between our geographic markets as well as through different business models and
product offerings. We compete with other dedicated off-price players, full-price platforms that offer discounted
in-season and end-of-season fashion, as well as players within the wider fashion e-commerce landscape. Within
the dedicated off-price market, our competitors include ZalandoLounge, Veepee, Brands4Friends, Limango,
Dress for Less and Otrium. However, we believe that our business model and proposition is fundamentally
different to these players. Many of these players pursue a flash-sale model, whereby the company offers a discount
for a short period of time on a limited number of products. We believe this is less appealing for customers as they
do not have access to a permanent assortment and often face long delivery times. The competitive landscape
within the discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion segment is more fragmented and includes full-price
platforms such as Zalando and Mytheresa.

We believe that our unique proposition distinctly separates us from the above-mentioned peers, from both a brand
and customer perspective. We are the only online off-price player to operate a closed membership model by
invitation-only which allows us to offer much greater brand equity protection than our competitors who typically
employ mass marketing. We are also able to purchase large quantities of overstock directly from our brand partners
and so are well positioned to provide a structural and silent solution for their overstock. From a customer
perspective, we offer a permanent assortment, unlike many of our competitors that focus on a flash-sale model.
This gives us a strong advantage given the resulting longer delivery times that are associated with flash-sale
models, and speed of delivery being a key factor in the customer experience. Our membership model also offers
a high degree of exclusivity resulting in a highly loyal and active customer base. We believe we offer an experience
that is at least on par with full-price platforms like Zalando, About You or Mytheresa, while offering our customers
attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80% across our standing assortment.

**OUR BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the off-price market with a
focus on mid-market to luxury fashion in Europe. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio
of around 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a
discreet and controlled channel and protecting their brand equity. With a heritage going back nearly 100 years,
we have evolved from an offline retail business to a tech-driven online platform. We offer a wide range of midmarket to luxury fashion brands at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80%, providing a permanent
assortment of approximately 250,000 items at any moment in time. Our online offering is available in multiple
languages and in 27 European countries. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we generated revenue of
€996.3 million, an Adjusted EBITDA of €131.4 million and an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.2%. Our online
revenue, which accounted for 91.7% of total revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, grew at a
CAGR of 41.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022.
While 70.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 was generated in Germany, our
international business outside of Germany continues to gain in importance relative to our Germany business and
experienced strong revenue growth of 86.3% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 (with a CAGR of 62.2%
from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022).

**Strengths**

We believe that our business is characterized by a number of key strengths that set it apart from our competitors:

**_Our business operates successfully in a large and resilient market with long-term growth supported by_**
**_structural tailwinds_**

We operate in the European online fashion market (excluding Russia and the United Kingdom) for mid-market to
luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season sectors. By
targeting the online off-price sector, we are well-positioned to take advantage of three structural long-term trends
in the fashion sector: (1) disproportional demand growth in the off-price market, expected to grow at 5% per year
from 2021-2025, (2) a shift to more premium fashion, with the mid-market to luxury fashion market expected to
grow at 4% per year from 2021-2025 and (3) rising online penetration in the European fashion market, expected
to grow at 9% per year from 2021-2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis).

The growing importance of sustainability for consumers and brands makes the off-price sector an increasingly
attractive choice for brands, as it allows for overstock, a structural phenomenon in the fashion industry, to be
monetized in a sustainable manner, at discounted prices to consumers and thus avoiding the destruction or disposal
of such overstock in landfills. Our closed-membership model offers brands the additional value of discreet
overstock clearing at scale and we believe it presents a unique business opportunity to build upon the growing
importance of sustainability.

As a result of the above factors, and as illustrated in the chart below, the online off-price sector amounted to
€44 billion in revenue across Europe (excluding the U.K. and Russia) in 2021, and is expected to grow at a CAGR
of 12% from 2021 to 2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis).

**_The most powerful flywheel in online fashion_**

The “flywheel” that drives our growth and profitability is the result of several strong elements that feed into one
another and that accelerate our viral engine. First, we develop strong brand relationships as a result of our closed
and discreet model that allows us to “silently” clear our brand partners’ overstock at scale. Second, based on our
strong brand relationships we are able to offer our members a current and attractive assortment of highly desirable
brands at discounts ranging from 20% to 80%. Third, we believe this in turn, leads to our members preferring to
shop with us, as reflected by exceptional customer key performance indicators (“KPIs”). In combination, these
three favorable elements lead to a continuous acceleration of our “viral engine” in which existing members make
use of their invitation rights to invite their families and friends. As a consequence, the “flywheel” has generated
low double-digit top line growth every year, thereby attracting new brand partners and reinforcing relationships
with existing brand partners. Our viral engine has contributed to an exponential growth engine as illustrated in the

_Our brand partners_

Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model enables brands to discreetly clear large volumes of overstock
in a premium environment entirely separate from their full-price channels. Discretion is increasingly important to
brands, as overstock potentially threatens brand equity when sold openly, because the high degree of price
visibility in online shopping allows customers to view full-price and discounted offerings side-by-side.

We recently introduced a marketplace as part of our online platform to provide our brand partners the option to
market their products within our ecosystem without us having to hold these products in our own inventory. We
believe that the marketplace model will strengthen the relationship with our brand partners as it allows them to
increase their direct to customer (or “DTC”) revenue through our online platform while maintaining price control.
We offer brand partners to clear their overstock within a closed ecosystem. This also provides our brand partners
comfort that their merchandise is not being re-sold through the grey market (i.e., channels that our brand partners
have not authorized) or other channels that could harm their brand image. Thus, our discreet model protects their
brand equity and fosters our long-term and deep strategic partnerships leading to direct relationships with around
95% of all our brand partners, thereby avoiding intermediaries. Our model has also resulted in high brand partner
retention: we have retained all of our top 50 brand partners from 2017 (excluding intermediaries, private label
suppliers and suppliers who went out of business). These strong relationships allow us to offer attractive products
at desirable prices, which in turn, allow us to provide our brand partners with access to an affluent and loyal
customer base.

_Our products, prices and services_

Our superior brand proposition in turn leads to our ability to offer highly desirable products at attractive prices to
our customers and provide them with a service experience matching that of full-price online platforms. Our brand
proposition and the resulting strong relationships ensure that we are able to secure an attractive brand portfolio of
around 3,000 brands, comprising approximately 250,000 articles at any given time. Unlike almost all other online
platforms in the off-price segment, our offered assortment is broad and available permanently: we do not rely on
flash sales campaigns with long delivery times. Furthermore, our customers benefit from a fresh assortment: the
majority of our inventory has been listed on our online platform for less than six months. This desirable assortment
is complemented by attractive discounts of 20% to 80% on every single article and a fast delivery time of
approximately 3 days on average in 2021.

Our online platform is accessible to our customers through our highly rated app and website which offers a highend shopping and service experience on par with leading online full-price platforms, resulting in high customer
satisfaction and an excellent net promoter score (“NPS”) of approximately 60 at the end of 2021. As the fashion
market and its consumers increasingly make sustainability a driver of their purchasing decisions, we expect that
they will increasingly turn to us for their fashion needs, as our model allows customers a chance to shop fashion
in one of the most sustainable ways by giving them access to overstock and ensuring that every piece of fashion
that is produced is worn.

_Viral engine_

Our “viral engine” is a self-reinforcing model in which existing members invite their friends, colleagues or other
acquaintances, thus creating multiple new customers. These new members then repeat the cycle, allowing a single
original customer to lead to substantial growth over time.

New “viral customers” are the primary drivers of our year-on-year structural revenue growth and an important
driver for our expansion. Our viral engine resulted in our online business revenue growing at a CAGR of 22%
from 2016 to 2020, after which time we introduced our paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter
of 2021. Moreover, the viral engine is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue
being spent annually to incentivize customers to invite other customers. The overall effect of this viral model is
substantial, with four new active customers generated by ten active customers in 2021.

**Strategy**

To build on our existing success, we have identified the following key elements of our strategy:

**_Driving customer growth with paid customer acquisition_**

To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the
second quarter of 2021. Paid marketing efforts help us to invite potential new members who will act as new base
for future viral growth in underpenetrated regions where we want to grow the most. These new members will
drive our future viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral engine.
Paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer demographics and regions to drive our non-viral
growth in areas in which we have currently a low customer penetration (such as Northern Germany and
international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly favorable marketing efficiency ratio
(defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy divided by marketing spend) and has
maintained short payback periods while scaling marketing investment. Moreover, our paid marketing strategy is
closely aligned with our brand partners. As illustrated in the chart below, we have experienced strong profitability

expand into new international markets and increase penetration in our existing markets: (1) targeting and

**_Establishing the leading European off-price marketplace_**

In 2021, we introduced a new marketplace model. Through our marketplace model, we offer our brand partners
to market their products on our BestSecret online platform without having BestSecret to hold these products as

online platform. We expect to achieve full scale operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022.
Through the expansion of our marketplace offering, we aim to expand our assortment through acquiring new
brand partners in the luxury segment and further grow the end of season fashion segment on BestSecret. We view

**_Taking advantage of the consolidation trend_**

The dedicated online off-price sector in Germany, our core region, is expected to undergo significant consolidation
through 2025, when the top five market participants are expected to command 68% of the market. This
consolidation is predicted to be driven by brands reducing the number of their distribution partners, the increasing

and Switzerland, we are in a strong position to take advantage of the consolidation trend within the European
market. Our scale, our highly professionalized operations and our value proposition to clear overstock in a discrete
manner underline our advantageous position towards brands. With the aim of further benefitting from the
consolidation trend, we will continue to invest in increasingly scaling our business and advancing our offering.

**Our History**

BestSecret draws on a heritage of nearly 100 years in the textile industry. In 1924, Herman Schustermann founded
a textile company in Makredwitz, Germany and relocated to Munich in the late 1940s. In the early 1950s, Benno
Borenstein established his textile business in Munich. The two companies merged in 1960, and, after the death of
Herman Schustermann, a new cooperation was established with Herman’s son, Emil Schustermann, and Benno
Borenstein as partners. While Schustermann & Borenstein initially started out as a combination of two textile
trading companies with regional customer bases around Munich, ready-to-wear clothes were added to the portfolio
over the next decades and the closed membership retail business model was born.

Prior to 2007, our business operations were limited to our Schustermann & Borenstein offline retail stores in
Munich. In 2007, we launched our BestSecret online platform. In 2011, we made the BestSecret online platform
available in the Austrian market, setting the first milestone for our international expansion strategy. Since then,
we have continued our online expansion with the launch of our online presence in Sweden (2015), Switzerland
(2015), France (2016), The Netherlands (2018) and, most recently, Belgium (2021) and Poland (2022). Today,
our multi-language online platform is available across Europe with shipping available to 27 countries. We have
continued to maintain a limited physical presence with premium and outlet stores in strategic locations, with such
locations designed primarily to support our online platform.

In 2012, the BestSecret Group’s founding families sold a majority stake of 61% of the business to Ardian. In 2014,
construction commenced on the new centralized fulfillment center in Poing, Germany (near Munich), which
became operational in early 2016 and consolidated our then-existing seven warehouses. In 2014, we expanded
our offline retail footprint through the opening of a new store in Vienna, Austria. In 2016, we acquired Swiss
Online Shopping AG, a leading off-price player in Switzerland, to further expand our online presence in Germany,
Austria and Switzerland (hereafter referred to as the DACH region). In January 2017, funds owned and managed
by Permira acquired a majority stake in the Group. In 2019 and 2020, we expanded our fulfillment center in Poing,
Germany by approximately 60% to support our business growth.

In late 2020, Dr. Moritz Hahn joined us after nine years of experience at Zalando SE where he served as a member
of the Executive Committee and held numerous senior positions. He has since built a strong leadership team of ecommerce pioneers with decades of relevant experience across the tech and e-commerce industry, complemented
by senior individuals with long-term experience at and in-depth knowledge of the Company. In early 2021, this
senior leadership team announced the new vision “to become the number one online destination for off-price
fashion in Europe.” The accompanying strategy is focused on online pure-play, profitable growth across Europe.
The offline strategy was sharpened to focus on supporting our online value proposition with premium stores
designed to elevate our brand image and outlet stores to clear inventory that fails to sell online. In 2021, the
structure and brand profile across the Group was simplified and harmonized, merging and renaming the companies
to solely feature the BestSecret name across the Group.

with other leading online full-price platforms. With our unique proposition, dedicated customer service,
comprehensive VIP Program and exclusive partnerships, we reward and care for our customers and seek to
transform them into loyal members of our community.

Our value proposition to customers:

  - We provide attractive discounts of 20% to 80% – on every article.

**_Supply_**

_Brands and merchandise offering_

Our ability to build long-term relationships with our brand partners is key to ensuring that we have first access to
their stock lists. We have been able to retain business relationships with all of our top 50 brands partners from
2017 (excluding intermediaries, private label suppliers and suppliers that went out of business). During the twelve
months ended March 31, 2022, we offered merchandise from approximately 3,000 brands on average. This has
contributed to the breadth of our product portfolio and ensures that we are not dependent on any brand partner or
fashion trend. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our largest brand partner accounted for approximately 4%
of total revenue. Our top ten brand partners together accounted for less than 20% of our revenue in the same
period. Due to the scale of our platform, we are able to purchase large volumes from our brand partners. We have
significantly increased our purchasing budget in-line with the strong growth in our business. At the same time,
our brand partners are reducing their number of total online off-price partners, and as the leading online off-price
player in Germany by revenue, we believe we are well positioned to benefit from this market consolidation.

We are currently implementing sourcing initiatives that enable us to screen and add new brand partners with a
proven and systematic approach while allowing us to scale our biggest partners faster.

We actively manage our supplier base in order to continuously align with the assortment and volumes of
merchandise we require for our business. This enables us to maintain a fresh selection of merchandise year-round
– as of March 31, 2022, more than 60% of our products had been in stock for less than six months and more than
90% for less than one year.

For the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, by product category, our revenue comprised 34% womenswear,
25% menswear, 6% kids, 13% shoes, 8% sports and 14% accessories and other categories (including, bags,
jewelry, among others).

Our buying strategy combines overstock with in-season and end-of-season orders, as well as pre-season collection
orders, to allow us to offer seasonally relevant merchandise and a permanent assortment to our customers, while
providing additional revenue to our brand partners. We supplement our merchandise from our brand partners with
our private label merchandise. Our merchandising teams supports our buying teams in driving sales and
profitability by managing inventory investments and driving efficiencies in the purchasing process. Key elements
of this integrated approach include financial planning, assortment planning, open-to-buy inventory management,
merchandise allocation and management of initial and markdown pricing to enhance gross margin and improve
inventory quality.

Consistent with customary practice in our industry, our relationships with many of our brand partners are not
based on formalized supply agreements but, rather, the regular submission of purchase orders or price agreements
renegotiated periodically between the parties on order forms.

Because our assortment is permanent, rather than following the flash-sale models of other off-price platforms (in
which a discount or promotion is offered by the off-price platform for a short period of time), we are able to
provide this broad selection to our customers at any time. As a result, our brand partners can sell their overstock
to us on the spot, without having to wait for a flash-sale window.
