_Marketplace_

In addition to our core wholesale model through which we sell the purchased inventory of branded fashion
merchandise at attractive discounts, we introduced a new marketplace model in the year ended December 31,
2021. Through our marketplace model, we offer third-party fashion brands the option to market their products on
our BestSecret online platform on own terms without us acquiring these products. We expect to achieve full scale
operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022.

The new marketplace is one of the core pillars of our growth strategy. Our marketplace model has helped us
expand into the market for discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion and we are well-positioned to provide
our customers with a wider product assortment, which we expect to drive incremental revenue. We also expect
the additional products to be from affordable luxury or luxury brands, who tend to prefer marketplace models that
give them more control over merchandise presentation and prices. The expanded product selection could
potentially contribute to an increase in order size and a reduction in the likelihood of products being out of stock,
as we attract more multi-channel brands who hold their own stock in existing product categories. We believe that
these features will further support our position as the go-to destination for online off-price fashion, increasing
customer satisfaction and loyalty.

Furthermore, we anticipate that the marketplace model will increase our profitability through commissions with
attractive economics, while having limited inventory and working capital impact. We expect warehousing and
fulfillment will typically remain in the hands of third-party suppliers. Our marketplace suppliers are also able to
rely on us for fulfillment at their option, which will allow us to benefit from incremental fulfillment fees on
marketplace sales.

**Operations**

To promote customer satisfaction, we aim to make online off-price fashion shopping on our BestSecret online
platform as convenient as possible along the entire customer journey. Therefore, the operational activities forming
the backbone of our online platform BestSecret consist of four business activities (and corresponding
departments): providing our onsite product content, offering convenient payment options, handling outbound and
return logistics and answering our customers’ queries.

**_Content Management_**

As an online fashion platform, our product content is key to helping our customers decide whether to order a
product or not, consequently driving sales and avoiding unwanted returns. Our content, both images and text,
needs to be accurate, inspiring yet realistic, complete yet relevant, and promote diversity to support our ESG goals.
Simultaneously, producing and/or onboarding this content should be fast and cost-effective.

In 2021, we provided content for over 400,000 color variants of our merchandise, reduced the time for content to
be published online by almost 40% (compared to the prior year) and restructured our content management team.
We completely outsourced the creation of all content to two specialized service providers that follow our content
guidelines, switched from virtual to real models for the production of the images and refocused our smaller internal
team on vendor management, quality management and content innovations.

**_Payment Methods_**

We offer different payment methods tailored to meet our members’ payment preferences, both in our stores and
online shop including credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and pay by invoice. We believe that
offering a wide array of payment methods enhances customer satisfaction and improves our check-out conversion
with respect to online sales.

**_Logistics_**

We operate a modern fulfillment center in Poing, near Munich, Germany. The facility was expanded by
approximately 60% in 2019 and 2020 to support our growing order volumes. The expansion enabled us to
regularly ship more than 400,000 online orders with more than 1.4 million items per week during the fourth quarter
of 2021. We believe our logistics operations are well-positioned to sustain our future growth with an average
increase of 55% in the number of online orders shipped per week from 2020 to 2021. The extended site in Poing
now has a size of 173,000 square meters (on a footprint of 48,000 square meters) and can hold up to 14 million
items of inventory. Our main fulfillment center in Poing is supported by a network of three smaller sites which

125


-----

are operated by third-party providers that we brought online in 2021 to support our high growth. These additions
increased our total storage capacity to approximately 18 million items of inventory.

We are in the process of launching a second fulfillment center in Poland, which is expected to start its operations
in 2023. We anticipate that once this new fulfillment center is fully ramped up in 2024, it will more than double
our current storage capacity at a lower operating expense than our existing network.

In addition to our fulfillment centers, our logistics network also includes one externally operated returns
processing center in Poland that specializes in processing all returns. In the period from January 1, 2019 to
March 31, 2022, approximately 99% of all items have been sold within our ecosystem, with only approximately
1% of returned items being too damaged to be re-sold.

In addition to managing our fulfillment and returns center network, we provide a smooth and fast delivery and
returns experience at low cost to our customers, with an average delivery time of approximately 3.2 days across
our focus markets. We regularly review our supply chain and last-mile setup according to customer expectations
and our company priorities. For example, in 2021, we improved the delivery experience for our Dutch customers
by switching to a faster last-mile carrier and by reducing delivery lead-times by one to two days on average.

**_Customer Service_**

Our customer service team is available to help whenever a customer has a question or a problem. The customer
service team also strives to help us understand why our customers contact us in the first place and to ensure we
address the underlying root causes. In 2021, these efforts resulted in a reduction of our contact rate per order by
11%. We offer support through telephone, e-mail, and our self-help section on the website. In 2021, the team
handled approximately 900,000 e-mails and calls through three external vendors, the third of which went live in
2021 to support the peak volumes typical for the fourth quarter. In addition to fast service with a high contact
resolution rate, we focus on offering convenient contact hours in our customers’ local language. We currently
support in German (with local agents for our Swiss customers), English, Dutch, French and Swedish and Polish.

**Marketing**

The growth of our sales depends on the success of our “viral engine” model and continued incentive programs for
customer referrals from existing members. We use various tools, such as daily e-mail newsletters, push
notifications as well as social media to support the positioning of our brand, acquire new members and retain
existing customers, as well as increase the number of customer visits to our websites, the number of their orders
and their basket size per order.

**_Highly Engaged Customers_**

Our number of active customers was approximately 1.2 million, 1.5 million and 2.3 million for the years ended
December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, and 2.5 million for the twelve
months ended March 31, 2022, representing a CAGR of 38% between 2019 and 2021. We have established deep
relationships with our customers, leading to outstanding retention rates, strong order economics, and high
customer engagement. In the year ended December 31, 2021, our customers placed a total of 12.7 million orders.

Our customer loyalty program (which we refer to as the “VIP Program”) is designed to deepen our customer
relationships. The VIP Program includes three levels of status based on a point system: Silver (more than 300
points), Gold (more than 1,500 points) and Diamond (more than 2,500 points). Members collect points for each
online purchase, with €1 spent (after returns) translating into one status point, as well as for recommending new
active customers and other activities (such as newsletter subscriptions or special sales events), which we promote
regularly. As of March 31, 2022, more than 75% have a VIP status. All Silver, Gold and Diamond members
receive commissions in the form of vouchers and commissions for referrals of new active customers and receive
a limited number of invitations which they can extend to potential new customers. Depending on their status, our
members receive additional invitation vouchers, free priority shipping and sneak previews of new merchandise
and benefit from the advantage of a 30-day free return period.

**_Viral Engine_**

With our “viral engine” model, existing customers invite new customers. Our online revenue has grown at a
CAGR of 22% from 2016 to 2020 as a result of the viral model, which we complemented with the introduction of
our new paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter of 2021. To push our viral growth, we utilize a
customer experience toolset that allows us to collect meaningful data for behavioral key drivers and helps us to

126


-----

understand the dynamics behind our viral engine, enabling us to further drive viral growth. Our viral engine is
therefore tied into our membership system which grants customers a limited number of invitation rights that can
be shared with friends and family. New invitees become members and get access to our assortment of products
and also receive a limited number of invitation rights after their first purchase. Our viral model leads to exponential
customer growth, expressed by an average of 16 active customers in 2021 stemming from a single customer that
became active in 2009.

**_Paid Customer Acquisition_**

Beginning in the second quarter of 2021, paid marketing efforts have helped us to invite new potential members
to join our closed membership model who can then in turn make use of their invitation rights to invite new
members, thereby accelerating our viral engine. Targeted social media advertisements drive our customer growth,
especially in areas with currently low penetration (such as Northern Germany and international markets). This
“seeding” strategy has been implemented with scaled marketing expenses, while maintaining short payback
periods. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key
_Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition.”_

While we operate mostly online, our physical premium and outlet stores in Germany and Austria continue to be

offer certain in-season fashion offline prior to an online listing. Our premium stores offer a high-street shopping
experience with primarily in-season brand collections at considerable discounts to the recommended retail price,
with products typically arranged by key brands and presented, in some cases, in dedicated brand areas.

Our outlet stores serve as a sales channel for the overstock we are unable to sell profitably online anymore, such
as high-return, single size or color articles and goods of second choice. This allows us to live up to our commitment
to conduct our business in an environmentally responsible and sustainable way by selling the almost all of
merchandise we receive from our brand partners within our ecosystem. Finally, our stores round off our customer
proposition by providing us with an opportunity to interact with customers who still prefer to shop offline. With
the combination of our physical retail stores and our online platform, we sold approximately 99% of all items
within our ecosystem in 2021, with only approximately 1% of returned items being too damaged to be re-sold.
Only items that are severely damaged and cannot be worn anymore are not sold in our outlets, representing a
negligible part of our stock.

Our offline retail store portfolio primarily comprises four free-standing sites. Two sites are located in Munich,
Germany, one site is located in Dresden, Germany, and a fourth site is located in Vienna, Austria. Each of our
sites is located on the periphery of the city center (i.e., off high street locations) which translates into higher sales
density, lower rent expenses and attractive cost-margin advantages.

**Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) Matters**

Based on numbers from recent years, 85% of all textiles in the fashion industry end up on landfills. Also, the
fashion industry is responsible for 10% of global carbon dioxide emissions. We believe our business model
inherently contributes to more environmental sustainability in the fashion industry. By focusing on overstock
clearance, we help ensure that nearly every piece of fashion that is fit-to-wear finds an owner, thereby reducing
the amount of fashion that is discarded as waste. In fact, in the year ended December 31, 2021, 79% of our total
NMV was overstock merchandise. We give fashion its first life, just as second-hand retailers provide products
with a second life. In addition, our online off-price model provides our customers with a more sustainable
alternative to shopping in remote outlet centers. The majority of studies conducted on the topic conclude that
online shopping on average leads to lower carbon emissions compared to in-store shopping. This can be attributed
to consolidated shipments and well-utilized infrastructure and is especially the case for deliveries that replace
private transport over long distances.

We support and complement our online platform with our physical premium and outlet stores in Germany and
Austria, which allow us to sell returns which we would have not been able to sell online because they have not
met our strict quality standards after we have received them.

We have made ESG one of our corporate priorities. In addition to our inherently sustainable business model, we
plan to further increase sustainability in what we sell and how we sell through our own Sustainability Program.
As part of this program, we strive to create a positive environmental and social impact, balancing the needs of our
brand partners, customers, employees, investors, the environment, and wider society with the ultimate goal of
becoming an even more sustainable online fashion company.

Further, as part of our commitment to ESG, we recently published our sustainability report and are planning to
publish this report annually going forward.

**_Our Business Model and Sustainability Program_**

We aim to be part of the solution to the fashion industry’s overstock sustainability challenge: By focusing on
overstock clearance, we aim to reduce resource use and waste in the fashion industry. While second-hand retailers
work on extending the active use time of items and providing them with a second life, we aim to make sure that
every piece of fashion has its first life. In addition, we also initiated our Sustainability Program to establish clear
initiatives and transparent criteria against which we will measure our progress to becoming even more sustainable.
We think of sustainability in two broad categories: what we sell (our articles) and how we sell it to our customers
(our orders). Within these two broad categories, we have chosen to focus on environmental and social matters, in
accordance with the external standards most relevant for the fashion industry.

**_Our Governance and Management_**

We have created a governance structure to promote responsibility and accountability for ESG matters across the
Company. Furthermore, we have also implemented a meeting and alignment structure that we believe will allow
us to progress in our ESG efforts through regular alignments and meetings, in particular in our Sustainability
Steering Committees and our broader Sustainability team, as well as through reporting back to our Advisory
Board.

**Regulatory Environment**

We operate in several countries and our business is subject to various regulatory requirements under the laws of
the European Union (“EU”) and national laws in relevant countries. Laws and regulations applicable to our
operations may differ due to different national and local laws. Applicable regulatory requirements relate, in
particular, to our dealing with customers, consumer protection, and the processing of customer data.

By creating a common regulatory framework for the member states of the European Union (“EU Member
**States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our**
business. EU law comprises both directives as well as regulations. While the latter apply directly in all EU Member

130


-----

States, EU directives need to be transposed into national law. Therefore, standards contained in EU directives may
slightly differ from one EU Member State to another depending on the actual implementation into national law.

The following section provides a brief overview of selected EU and German legislation and regulations which are
applicable to our business. Similar laws and regulations also apply to our business in other jurisdictions in which
we operate.

**_Data Protection_**

The processing of personal data within the EU and the EEA is primarily governed by the General Data Protection
Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (Datenschutz-Grundverordnung, “GDPR”) which became effective on May 25, 2018.
The GDPR applies to any enterprise that is processing the personal data of living individuals (data subjects) within
the EU/EEA regardless of its location and the data subjects’ citizenship or residence. It is also applicable where
the processing activities are related to (1) the offering of goods or services, irrespective of whether a payment of
the data subject is required, to such data subjects in the EU/EEA, or (2) the monitoring of data subject’s behavior
as far as their behavior takes place within the EU/EEA. The GDPR aims primarily to give control to individuals
over their personal data and to simplify the regulatory environment for international business by harmonizing the
EU regulatory framework of data protection.

Under the GDPR, personal data may only be processed for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and only if
the processing is covered by a legal basis (e.g., consent of the data subject, if it is necessary for the performance
of a contract, to comply with a legal obligation, or if we rely on our overriding legitimate interests). Furthermore,
data subjects must be informed transparently before the processing of personal data about the circumstances of
the intended processing activities (e.g., purposes, retention periods, recipients of the personal data). This aims to
enable the data subjects to effectively exercise their rights under the GDPR (e.g., the right of access to or the right
to erasure of their personal data, if the relevant requirements are met). Furthermore, the GDPR provides restrictive
requirements as regards solely automated decision making and profiling activities, which could for example
impact marketing activities based on such processing of personal data.

The GDPR also stipulates that certain technical and organizational measures must be implemented to protect the
personal data depending on the amount of and potential risk for the personal data processed. These measures may
include physical security against unauthorized access and manipulation, password security, reasonable encryption
as well as protection against accidental data loss, destruction, or damage. Based on the general accountability
principle of the GDPR, the processing activities and the corresponding data protection measures must be
sufficiently documented (such as keeping records of processing activities). Furthermore, under the GDPR, special
care and safeguards must also be taken when transferring personal data to countries outside the EEA to ensure
that a level of data protection equivalent to the EU is in place for the processing of personal data. Recent legal
developments in the EU, e.g., the ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union (“CJEU”) of July 16, 2020
(case no C-311/18, Data Protection Commissioner v Facebook Ireland Limited and Maximillian Schrems, socalled “Schrems II”), have created complexity and uncertainty regarding such data transfers.

The GDPR provides for fines of up to €20.0 million or 4% of global turnover on a group basis, whichever is
greater and depending on the respective breach for non-compliance with GDPR provisions. Failure to comply
with the GDPR can also result in claims for compensation for financial or non-financial damages claimed by
individuals under Article 82 GDPR and cease and desist claims. Non-compliance may further result in
proceedings or actions against us by governmental authorities, including corresponding costs for litigation, or
require us to change our operations and/or cease or modify our use of certain personal data sets. We may also be
contractually required to indemnify and hold harmless third parties from the costs or consequences of
non-compliance with data protection requirements. Individual EU Member States, like Germany, also provide
criminal sanctions for specific severe violations. Finally, in addition to these regulatory risks, infringement of the
GDPR can lead to reputational risk and significantly undermine customers’ trust in our business.

In the event of a breach of the protection of personal data, we are required to submit data breach notifications to
the relevant local data protection authorities (“DPAs”) within 72 hours beginning with the awareness of a possible
breach. If the breach concerned entails a high risk to the rights of the data subjects, they also need to be informed.
Data subjects, DPAs and competitors, as well as consumer associations, and other authorized associations may
pursue claims, including potentially mass litigation, against us for breach of the GDPR.

We are subject to the supervision of the Bavarian State Office for Data Protection Supervision (Bayerisches
_Landesamt für Datenschutzaufsicht). To comply with regulatory requirements imposed on us, we have, inter alia,_
established a data protection organization as well as data protection processes, including, without limitation,

131


-----

appointing data protection officers, where required, and have implemented data protection policies for all
employees dealing with personal data. However, the task of meeting all the data protection law requirements is
complex, in particular taking into account that there are still material legal uncertainties in various respects and
that data protection authorities continuously publish more detailed GDPR guidance.

In addition to the GDPR, the German Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, “BDSG”) applies
to the processing of personal data within Germany. The BDSG provides further data protection rules by making
use of derogation and opening clauses in the GDPR. It stipulates, inter alia, additional requirements to limitations
on the scope of data subjects’ rights and personal data processing in the employment context. Other EU Member
States implemented similar local data protection acts.

Furthermore, based on its data strategy, the European Union plans to comprehensively further revise the legal
framework for the handling data, for example through the proposed Digital Markets Act and the Digital Services
Act. Such future changes of the legal framework may have further impacts to our processing of data.

**_Telemedia Law_**

Our business activities are also subject to the German Telecommunication and Telemedia Data Protection Act
(Telekommunikation-Telemedien-Datenschutz-Gesetz, “TTDSG”), which came into force on December 1, 2021
and consolidates the previous data protection regulations of the German Telecommunication Act
(Telekommunikationsgesetz, “TKG”) and the German Telemedia Act (Telemediengesetz, “TMG”). To the extent
the TTDSG transposes the provisions of EU Directive 2002/58/EC on privacy and electronic communications
(“ePrivacy Directive”), it prevails over the GDPR.

The TTDSG provides special data protection rules and also stipulates provisions on the use of cookies and similar
technologies, regardless of whether the data is personal data or not. Generally, the end user must actively consent
to the use of cookies and similar technologies on the basis of clear and comprehensive information, except for
cookies and similar technologies that are technically strictly essential for a service requested by the end user and
for cookies and similar technologies that are used exclusively for the transmission of messages via a public
telecommunications network. This is also in line with recent case law by the European Court of Justice and the
German Federal Court (Bundesgerichtshof), which have both specified the requirements on the use of cookies.
These provisions and rulings are relevant for our online business and the use of web tracking tools, each of which
relies on cookies and similar technologies, and must be taken into account by all website operators.

In addition, the TTDSG stipulates that we as a telemedia service provider must implement certain technical and
organizational measures in order to protect our customers’ data and our IT systems (e.g., protection against
unauthorized access and (technical) interference).

The TMG continues to remain relevant to the extent information requirements are not superseded by either the
GDPR or the TTDSG. The TMG requires telemedia service providers to provide certain information on their
website, such as name and address and contact details (Section 5 TMG).

Non-compliance with the provisions on cookies and similar technologies under the TTDSG may result in
monetary fines of up to €300,000.

Moreover, the requirements for the use of cookies and similar technologies is constantly evolving. For example,
there is a draft Regulation of Privacy and Electronic Communications (“ePrivacy Regulation”) that would replace
the current ePrivacy Directive and national implementation laws, such as German implementation laws in the
TTDSG. While the text of the ePrivacy Regulation is still under development, data protection authorities’ recent
guidance is driving increased attention to cookies and similar technologies.

**_Consumer Protection Laws_**

We are affected by consumer protection laws that apply to businesses generally and, in particular, to businesses
that operate on the internet. At the EU level, consumer protection is comprehensively regulated by various
directives, inter alia:

  - Directive (EU) 2019/771 of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 20, 2019 on certain
aspects concerning contracts for the sale of goods (“EU **Sales of Goods Directive”);**

  - Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of October 25, 2011, as amended,
on consumer rights;

132


-----

  - Directive 2005/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 11, 2005, as amended,
concerning unfair business-to-consumer commercial practices in the internal market;

  - Directive 2000/31/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of June 8, 2000 on certain legal
aspects of information society services, in particular electronic commerce, in the Internal Market
(“eCommerce Directive”);

  - Council Directive 93/13/EEC of April 5, 1993, as amended, on unfair terms in consumer contracts;

  - Directive 98/6/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 16, 1998, as amended, on
consumer protection in the indication of the prices of products offered to customers.

With Directive (EU) 2019/2161 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 27, 2019 as regards
the better enforcement and modernization of Union consumer protection rules, the EU amended the existing EU
instruments for strengthened consumer protection. EU Member States had to transpose the new rules in their
national laws by November 28, 2021 and must apply these new national laws since May 28, 2022.

In Germany, for example, we are therefore subject to various laws concerning the protection of consumers, which
have been primarily laid down in the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch). Pursuant to these laws, we
are responsible for the conformity of the shipped products with the agreed or implied quality at the time the
purchase is made. And a consumer has certain statutory warranty rights (irrespective of our fault) should a product
be defective at the time of delivery. If a product is defective, consumers may generally require the retailer to repair
or replace the product in question free of charge.

The German Civil Code also regulates distance selling contracts (Fernabsatzverträge) to protect consumer
interests. The consumer benefits, among other things, from a statutory right of withdrawal from a distance selling
contract within a period of 14 days after the consumer has received the respective goods and has been informed
about his right of withdrawal in a manner compliant with the statutory requirements. During this time, a purchase
may be cancelled without any specific reason. If the consumer has not been properly informed about his/her
statutory right of withdrawal, the respective right expires twelve months and 14 days after receipt of the goods. If
customers exercise their right of withdrawal, they must return the goods and the retailer must refund the purchase
price, including any shipping costs originally charged. However, the retailer is not obliged to reimburse consumers
for any additional costs if the consumer has expressly opted for a more expensive type of delivery (e.g., express
delivery). On the other hand, the consumer must usually bear the costs of returning the goods, unless the retailer
failed to inform him or her accordingly or the retailer has expressly agreed to bear these costs. The consumer also
has to compensate the retailer for any loss in value of the returned goods in case such loss is due to the consumer’s
handling of the goods in a way that was not necessary to examine its condition, features and functionalities of the
product and the retailer has informed the consumer accordingly.

With the substantial 2022 reform of German contract law (Schuldrechtsreform 2022), the German legislator has
introduced further consumer-friendly regulations based on the EU Sales of Goods Directive, e.g., the reversal of
the burden of proof regarding the defectiveness of the purchased item at the time of handover at the expense of
the retailer extended from six months to one year. The introduced amendments to the German Civil Code entered
into force on January 1, 2022.

The German Civil Code, in connection with the Introductory Law to the German Civil Code (Einführungsgesetz
_zum Bürgerlichen Gesetzbuch), also stipulates that certain mandatory information must be provided to the_
consumer, including material characteristics of the purchased goods, the identity of the seller, terms of payment,
delivery and/or service, price and payment details and the statutory right of withdrawal.

In addition, in accordance with the German Price Indication Regulation (Preisangabenverordnung), retailers must
ensure, among other things, that the price of each product is displayed clearly, precisely and legibly and shall be
accessible, legible and intelligible on websites.

Against the backdrop of Directive (EU) 2019/2161 as regards the better enforcement and modernization of Union
consumer protection rules, the German Price Indication Regulation has been amended to include, as of May 28,
2022, new regulations for the announcement of price reductions for goods. The overall aim is to make the original
price on which a price reduction is based more transparent to the consumer. To this effect, each announcement of
a price reduction also has to state the lowest price applied by the retailer within a period of 30 days prior to the
application of the price reduction. The aim is also to put a stop to short-term price increases in advance of price

133


-----

reductions. Infringements of the Price Indication Obligation may constitute administrative offenses that can be
sanctioned with an administrative fine (Bußgeld) of up to €25,000.

We are also subject to rules and regulations relating to unfair competition in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
In particular, in Germany, competitors, consumer associations (Verbraucherverbände) and other authorized
associations may seek to enforce alleged violations of, or the failure to comply with, the Act Against Unfair
Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren Wettbewerb). Based on the Act Against Unfair Competition, unfair
commercial practices are illegal. Unfair commercial practices include, inter alia, commercial practices which are
misleading (including untrue information as to the existence of a special price advantage, the price or the manner
in which it is calculated), which constitute an unreasonable nuisance, which make use of harassment, coercion, or
undue influence, as well as unsolicited marketing (including unsolicited e-mail marketing).

Additionally, we must comply with information requirements relating to the European Online Dispute Resolution
(“ODR”) platform for consumers. On January 9, 2016, Regulation (EU) 524/2013 of the European Parliament
and of the Council of May 21, 2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes (“ODR Regulation”)
entered into force. It requires online retailers to disclose certain information on their websites to ensure that
consumers are aware of the new ODR possibilities. Another information requirement is set up by Directive
2013/11/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 21, 2013 on alternative dispute resolution for
consumer disputes (“ADR-Directive”). In Germany, for instance, the implementation act, the Consumer Dispute
Resolution Act (Verbraucherstreitbeilegungsgesetz) generally obliges online retailers to inform their customers
to what extent they are willing or obliged to participate in alternative dispute resolution procedures. Anyone who
has undertaken or is obliged to participate in dispute resolution proceedings must provide information on the
address and website of the competent alternative dispute resolution body.

**_Foreign Trade and Customs Law_**

We source many of our products within the European Union. Within the European internal market, the principle
of free movement of goods, as stipulated in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, applies. With
respect to import and export of goods from countries which are not members of the EU, we must comply with
national and European foreign trade and customs regulations. At the EU level our relevant regulatory framework
is based on the Union Customs Code (Regulation (EU) 952/2013). In Germany, the Foreign Trade and Payments
Act (Außenwirtschaftsgesetz) and the Ordinance on the Foreign Trade and Payments Act
(Außenwirtschaftsverordnung) constitute additional regulations which, _inter alia, set forth rules of procedure._
Infringements of customs or foreign trade regulations may be sanctioned with an administrative fine (Bußgeld) if
categorized as administrative offenses or with a fine (Geldstrafe) or custodial sentence (Freiheitsstrafe) if
categorized as criminal acts. Depending on the extent and nature of the underlying administrative offense, the
respective fine may amount to up to €30,000 for violations of procedural regulations and up to €500,000 for
violations of other regulations of the Foreign Trade and Payments Act. Even higher fines are possible in case of
skimming of profits (Gewinnabschöpfung). The authorities may from time to time undertake external audits
(Außenwirtschaftsprüfung) to assess whether we have complied with the regulations of the Foreign Trade and
Payments Act and the pertaining ordinances.

Whereas imports and exports within the EEA are in principle not liable to customs duty, the movement of goods
beyond the frontiers of the EEA may be subject to customs. The customs control charges, _inter alia, statutory_
import duties (Einfuhrabgaben). Customs offices may from time to time initiate customs inspections (Zollprüfung)
to assess whether customs regulations have been infringed.

The countries belonging to the EEA may charge customs duties if products are exported into such non-EEA
countries. We also distribute our products in Switzerland (which does not belong to the EEA). Switzerland,
however, is party to a preferential agreement (Präferenzabkommen), such agreements being concluded with the
European Union and certain other countries in order to facilitate the exchange of goods. The rate of customs duty
for goods exported into countries which are parties to the preferential agreement is considerably lower than the
regular customs duty rate. The customs administration assesses in a preference inspection (Präferenzprüfung) in
accordance with the Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/2447, as amended, which applies from
May 1, 2016, whether the requirements and conditions set forth in the preferential agreement are complied with.

**_Product Liability and Textile Labeling Law_**

In Germany, in addition to the general liability under civil law, we are in general subject to liability under the
Product Liability Act (Produkthaftungsgesetz) which is based on Council Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985
on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the EU Member States concerning

134


-----

liability for defective products. Under this act, we are liable, regardless of fault, for damage to life, body, health
and property caused by defective products to the extent we qualify as the “manufacturer” under the Product
Liability Act. This may be the case if we actually manufacture the products but also if we place our own logo or
name on the products of if we import the products into the EEA. The producer`s liability is limited to an amount
of €85 million. In the case of damage to property, the injured party has to pay for damages up to an amount of
€500.

Furthermore, although there is no coherent legal framework for trade in textiles in Germany, certain laws and
regulations may apply to us. For example, the German Food, Consumer Goods and Feed Act (Lebensmittel-,
_Bedarfsgegenstände- und Futtermittelgesetzbuch) and the German Ordinance on Consumer Goods_
(Bedarfsgegenständeverordnung) include special regulations which aim at preventing possible damage to human
health caused by textiles, especially due to toxic substances or contamination. Similarly, the German Chemicals
Prohibition Ordinance (Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung) prohibits the placing on the market of certain substances
and preparations as well as products containing such substances or preparations as listed in detail therein.
Furthermore, textiles may only be made available on the German market if they comply with the German Product
Safety Act (Produktsicherheitsgesetz) which is based on Directive 2001/95/EC of the European Parliament and
of the Council of December 3, 2001 on general product safety (“Product Safety Directive”) and complements
the EU regulations on market surveillance and compliance of products (Regulation (EC) 765/2008 of the European
Parliament and of the Council of July 9, 2008, as amended, setting out the requirements for accreditation and
market surveillance relating to the marketing of products and Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 of the European
Parliament and of the Council of June 20, 2019 on market surveillance and compliance of products). Under
German jurisdiction, this regulation is accompanied by the Market Surveillance Act (Marktüberwachungsgesetz)
which came into force on July 6, 2021.

These provisions on product safety apply to a wide variety of non-food products, including clothing and footwear
and are applicable to both the e-commerce and physical stores. They oblige retailers to ensure that their products
comply with applicable safety requirements. Moreover, a retailer is generally required to participate in the
monitoring of the safety of its products. Infringements of product safety regulations may be sanctioned with fines
and in severe cases with criminal sanctions.

We are further subject to the Regulation (EU) 1007/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of
27 September 2011 on textile fiber names and related labelling and marking of the fiber composition of textile
product pursuant to which textiles may only be made available on the European market if they are labeled or
marked with certain information, in particular regarding textile fibers. Depending on the implementing laws of
the EU member states, infringements of the textile labeling requirements may constitute administrative offenses.
In Germany the Regulation is supplemented by the Act on Textile Labeling (Textilkennzeichnungsgesetz). This
law creates the necessary conditions for effective enforcement of the Regulation (EU) 1007/2011 and, in
particular, lays down regulations on the powers of the authorities involved in market surveillance and on
administrative offences. Administrative offenses may be sanctioned with a fine of up to €10,000. Moreover,
violations of the provisions may be considered as unfair trade practices which are prohibited under the German
Act Against Unfair Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren Wettbewerb). As regards sold footwear, Directive
94/11/EC of European Parliament and Council of 23 March 1994, as amended, on the approximation of the laws,
regulations and administrative provisions of the EU Member States relating to labelling of the materials used in
the main components of footwear for sale to the consumer is applicable. The German legislator transposed the
directive into national law by means of the German Ordinance on Consumer Goods which contains regulations
concerning the content and form of footwear labeling.

**_Regulations on Packaging and Waste_**

We are subject to statutory provisions regarding waste management and packaging. Directive 2008/98/EC of the
European Parliament and of the Council of November 19, 2008 on waste (European Waste Framework Directive),
as amended, provides for the legislative basis of a recycling society in the EU. Its provisions on the collection,
transport, recovery and disposal of waste requires the EU Member States to take appropriate measures for
prevention of waste as a matter of priority and to ensure that waste is recovered or disposed of without endangering
human health or causing harm to the environment. In Germany, the main waste disposal provisions are set forth
in the Waste Management Act (Kreislaufwirtschaftsgesetz) which is supplemented and concretized by a number
of regulations.

Online retailers are subject to regulations on packaging. Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste
and its German implementation law, the Packaging Act (Verpackungsgesetz) aim to reduce the impact of
packaging waste on the environment. To this end, various obligations are imposed on the manufacturers and

135


-----

retailers. The German Packaging Act requires both to participate in a disposal and recycling system and imposes
certain takeback obligations. Typically, these requirements are complied with by registering one’s activities in the
German waste packaging register and paying a license fee based on the amount of packaging waste put into
circulation. In general, online retailers are only responsible for the shipping packaging. When importing products,
however, the retailer may also be responsible for sales packaging. Infringements of these regulations may be
sanctioned by administrative fines of up to €200,000.

**_Regulations on Cyber Security_**

We are also subject to regulations on cybersecurity. The GDPR and national laws like the German BDSG and
TTDSG require us to implement certain technical and organizational measures to protect our customers’ data and
IT systems. These measures may include physical security against unauthorized access and manipulation,
password security, reasonable encryption as well as protection against accidental data loss, destruction, or damage.
In case of a personal data breach, we are obliged to notify the breach to the competent data protection authority
within 72 hours after having become aware of it, unless the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to
the rights and freedoms of natural persons. When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the
rights and freedoms of natural persons, we are also required to communicate the personal data breach to the
affected data subject without undue delay.

**_Regulations on Payment Process_**

Directive (EU) 2015/2366 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 25, 2015 on payment
services in the internal market, among others, covers online-based payment services, provides for a uniform
regulation of payments via internet and mobile phones and increased customer protection and requirements for
user authentication, such as two-factor authentication. The German legislator has adopted the Law on the
transposition of Payment Services Directive Two (Gesetz zur Umsetzung der Zweiten Zahlungsdiensterichtlinie)
which mainly amended the German Payment Services Supervision Act (Zahlungsdiensteaufsichtsgesetz) and the
German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch).

**_Supply Chain Duty of Care Act_**

On June 25, 2021, the German Supply Chain Duty of Care Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz¸ “Supply
**Chain Duty of Care Act”) was passed and published in the Federal Law Gazette on July 16, 2021. The Supply**
Chain Duty of Care Act will become effective as of January 1, 2023, with the exception on certain administrative
regulations. The legislation will require affected companies to conduct adequate due diligence throughout their
supply chains in relation to human rights and (certain) environmental risks. This includes conducting a risk
analysis, establishing internal responsibilities for human rights and environmental protection, comprehensive
preventative measures, and grievance mechanisms. Additionally, companies concerned are obliged to
continuously document the fulfillment of due diligence obligations and to keep records in this respect for at least
seven years. In an annual report, which must be published on the company’s website and submitted electronically
to the competent authority, companies must report on their adherence to due diligence obligations. The report
needs to be submitted no later than four months after the end of the business year. Infringements of these
regulations may be sanctioned by administrative fines of up to €800,000. However, from January 1, 2023, the
Supply Chain Duty of Care Act will only be applicable to companies in Germany with generally at least 3,000
employees. From January 1, 2024, companies in Germany with generally at least 1,000 employees will be covered
as well. Therefore, our business does not have to comply with the Supply Chain Duty of Care Act until the later
date. The Supply Chain Duty of Care Act may be subject to change based on European legislation.

**MANAGEMENT**

**The Issuer**

The Issuer is a company with limited liability (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung) organized under the laws
of Germany. It was incorporated on July 19, 2016.

The Issuer is registered with the commercial register of the local court of Munich (Amtsgericht) under registration
number HRB 227078 and its registered office is Margaretha-Ley-Ring 27, 85609 Aschheim, Germany.

The managing directors of the Issuer are responsible for managing the day-to-day business of the Issuer in
accordance with applicable German law and its articles of association (Satzung) (the “Articles of Association”)
and the rules of procedure (Geschäftsordnung) for the board of managing directors of the Issuer. In addition, the
managing directors must ensure appropriate control of risk within the Issuer and its subsidiaries so that any
developments jeopardizing its future as a going concern may be identified at an early stage. The managing
directors legally represent the Issuer in dealings with third parties and in court. Currently, the Issuer has also
established an advisory board (Beirat) (the “Advisory Board”) in accordance with its Articles of Association.
The Advisory Board may not exercise management functions, it advises the managing directors on the
management of the Issuer and monitors its conduct of business.

The managing directors and the members of the Advisory Board owe duties of loyalty and care vis-à-vis the Issuer.
In discharging their duties, the members of these corporate bodies must consider a broad range of interests, which
in turn includes the interests of shareholders, employees, creditors and, to a certain extent, the general public. The
managing directors or the members of the Advisory Board are jointly and severally liable to the Issuer for any
damages that may arise if they fail to discharge their duties, provided that the liability of members of the Advisory
Board towards the Issuer is limited by the Articles of Association to willful misconduct and gross negligence.

As a basic principle under German law, a shareholder has no direct recourse against any managing director or
members of the Advisory Board in the event that they breach a duty _vis-à-vis the Issuer. Except as otherwise_
provided in the Articles of Association, only the shareholders’ meeting (Gesellschafterversammlung) of the Issuer
(the “Shareholders’ Meeting”) may exercise the right to bring claims for damages against the managing directors
or members of the Advisory Board.

The Issuer has taken out a directors and officers liability insurance policy for all managing directors and all
members of the Advisory Board.

The Shareholders’ Meeting may issue instructions which are binding upon the managing directors. Instructions
that would result in violations of mandatory provisions of German corporate law and in particular, capital
maintenance rules, are in any event prohibited.

**Managing Directors**

**_General Information_**

The managing directors are responsible for managing the business of the Issuer in accordance with the German
Limited Liability Companies Act (Gesetz betreffend die Gesellschaften mit beschränkter Haftung, GmbHG), its
Articles of Association and the rules of procedure (Geschäftsordnung) for the board of managing directors of the

managing director in conjunction with an authorized signatory who holds a power of attorney (Prokurist).

representation (Einzelvertretungsbefugnis) to certain or all of the managing directors.

**New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement**

**_Overview and structure_**

On or prior to the Issue Date, the Issuer (as an original borrower and an original guarantor), Holdco (as midco),
Best Secret GmbH (as an original borrower and an original guarantor), Best Secret Logistik GmbH (as an original
guarantor), Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, Goldman Sachs Bank Europe SE, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.,
London Branch and UniCredit Bank AG (as original lenders), UniCredit Bank AG (as facility agent) and
UniCredit Bank AG (as security agent) (amongst others) will enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement.

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides for borrowings of up to €110.0 million on a committed
basis. The New Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower under the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in euro, Swiss francs, sterling or certain other currencies (if agreed) by the
drawing of cash advances, the issue of Letters of Credit (the “Letters of Credit”) (upon the appointment of an
issuing bank) and by way of any Ancillary Facilities that may be made available thereunder (each as defined in
the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Subject to certain exceptions, loans may be borrowed, repaid and
re-borrowed at any time. Borrowings are available, amongst other things, to be used for general corporate and
working capital purposes of the Group (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) including,
without limitation, for payment of interest under the Notes.

In addition, the Issuer may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility or as additional tranches or
increase of an existing facility (including any previously incurred additional facility) under the New Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement (the “Additional Facility Commitments”) in amounts up to the Credit Facilities
Basket (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) or, to the extent it is exceeded, would
otherwise constitute Permitted Debt (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). The Issuer and
the lenders may agree to certain terms in relation to the Additional Facility Commitments, including the margin,
the maturity date and the availability period (each subject to parameters as set out in the New Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement). There are certain limitations (including as to maximum amount) on the ability to incur
Additional Facility Commitments.

**_Availability_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility may, subject to the satisfaction of customary conditions precedent, be utilized
from (and including) the Closing Date (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) until the date
falling one month prior to the maturity date of the New Revolving Credit Facility.

**_Borrowers and Guarantors_**

The Issuer is an original borrower and an original guarantor under the New Revolving Credit Facility. A
mechanism is included in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to enable certain of the Issuer’s
subsidiaries to accede as additional borrowers or additional guarantors under the New Revolving Credit Facility,
subject to certain conditions. The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also requires that, subject to, for the
avoidance of doubt, the section entitled “Guarantees” below, in the future each member of the Group (as defined
in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) which is or becomes a Material Company (as defined in the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement), or is otherwise required to become a guarantor in order to satisfy the
Guarantor Coverage Test (as defined below), becomes an additional guarantor under the New Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement and, where applicable, shall grant security over certain of its material assets in favor of the
Security Agent (subject to agreed security principles included in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement
(the “Agreed Security Principles”)).

143


-----

**_Maturity and Repayment Requirements_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility matures on the date falling 54 months after the Closing Date (as defined in
the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period
relating thereto, subject to a netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date. All outstanding
amounts under the New Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid in full on or prior to the maturity date for the
New Revolving Credit Facility. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the New Revolving Credit
Facility may be re-borrowed during its availability period, subject to certain conditions. The maturity date for a
facility under an Additional Facility Commitment is the date agreed between the Issuer and the relevant lenders.

**_Interest Rate and Fees_**

Loans under the New Revolving Credit Facility will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR
(in respect of loans denominated in euro), SONIA (in respect of loans denominated in sterling) or SARON (in
respect of loans denominated in Swiss francs) plus, in each case, an initial margin of 3.25% _per annum. The_
applicable margin in respect of the New Revolving Credit Facility shall be calculated in accordance with a margin
ratchet (subject to customary conditions).

A commitment fee is payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the New Revolving Credit
Facility at a rate of 30% of the then applicable margin. The commitment fee is payable quarterly in arrear on (i)
either (at the Issuer’s sole and absolute discretion) the last day of each successive period of three Months which
ends during the availability period or each quarter date occurring during the availability period (subject to certain
notification requirements); (ii) the last day of the availability period of the New Revolving Credit Facility; and
(iii) if cancelled, on the cancelled amount of the relevant lender’s commitment under the New Revolving Credit
Facility at the time such cancellation is effective.

Default interest on overdue amounts is calculated at a rate which is 1% higher than that rate applicable to the loans
under the New Revolving Credit Facility.

The Issuer is also required to pay customary agency fees to the facility agent and the Security Agent in connection
with the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

**_Guarantees_**

The Issuer, Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH will provide a senior guarantee of all amounts
payable to each Finance Party (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) by them or any of the
Issuer’s subsidiaries which accede to the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as additional borrowers or
additional guarantors.

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement requires that (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) each
subsidiary of the Issuer that is or becomes a Material Company (which definition includes, among other things,
any wholly-owned member of the Group (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement)
incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction (as defined below) and that has earnings before interest, tax, depreciation
and amortization representing more than 5% of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the New Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement), subject to certain exceptions)) will be required to become an additional guarantor under the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement within 180 days of the last date (including any applicable extension or
grace period) (or such later date as the facility agent may agree) on which the applicable annual financial
statements for the relevant fiscal year demonstrating that such subsidiary is a Material Company were required to
be delivered.

Furthermore, if on the last day of a fiscal year of the Issuer, the aggregate EBITDA of the guarantors under the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement represents less than 80% of the aggregate EBITDA of wholly-owned
members of the Group (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) incorporated in a Guarantor
Jurisdiction (as defined below) (on a consolidated basis and excluding the EBITDA of any on-balance sheet joint
ventures and any member of the Group (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) that is not
required to or cannot become a guarantor due to legal prohibitions or the Agreed Security Principles) (subject to
certain exceptions) (the “Guarantor Coverage Test”) the Issuer must, within 180 days of the last date (including
any applicable extension or grace period) (or such later date as the facility agent may agree) on which the
applicable annual financial statements for the relevant year were required to be delivered, cause sufficient
members of the Group (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) to accede to the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as additional guarantors (subject to the Agreed Security Principles and

144


-----

certain exceptions) to satisfy the Guarantor Coverage Test (to be calculated as if such additional guarantors had
been guarantors on such last day of the relevant fiscal year).

“Guarantor Jurisdiction” means Germany (provided that if a borrower under the New Revolving Credit Facility
is incorporated in a jurisdiction which is not a Guarantor Jurisdiction, the jurisdiction of that borrower shall
become a Guarantor Jurisdiction for the purposes of the Agreed Security Principles for so long as any borrower
is incorporated in such jurisdiction).

**_Security_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility will be (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) guaranteed by the Issuer,
Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH and secured on a pari passu basis by the same collateral that
secures the Notes as further described in the section entitled “Description of Notes—Security.”

Subject to any legal prohibitions and the Agreed Security Principles, the following transaction security shall be
granted as a condition precedent to the availability of the New Revolving Credit Facility: (i) Holdco shall grant
each of a German law governed third party limited recourse share pledge over its shares in the Issuer and a German
law governed third party limited recourse security agreement over any material structural intercompany loan
receivables owed to it by the Issuer; (ii) the Issuer shall grant each of a German law governed security agreement
in respect of any material bank accounts of the Issuer located in Germany, a German law governed share pledge
agreement or agreements over its shares in Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH, and a German law
governed security agreement over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it; (iii) Best
Secret GmbH shall grant a German law governed security agreement over any material structural intercompany
loan receivables owed to it; and (iv) Best Secret Logistik GmbH shall grant a German law governed security
agreement over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it.

Any Material Company or other member of the Group (each as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement) located in a Guarantor Jurisdiction, and, in each case, which becomes a guarantor under the New
Revolving Credit Facility, will (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) grant security in favour of the Security
Agent over (a) the shares it directly owns in any borrower under the New Revolving Credit Facility or any Material
Company and (b) if it is a borrower under the New Revolving Credit Facility or a Material Company, material
structural intra-group loan receivables owed to them.

No other security is required to be granted.

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties, subject
to certain customary materiality, actual knowledge and other qualifications, exceptions and baskets, including,
without limitation: (i) status and incorporation; (ii) binding obligations; (iii) non-conflict with constitutional
documents, laws or other obligations; (iv) power and authority; (v) authorizations; (vi) governing law and
enforcement; (vii) no event of default; (viii) no misleading information; (ix) accuracy of most recent financial
statements delivered; (x) no proceedings pending or threatened; (xi) taxation; (xii) pari passu ranking; (xiii) centre
of main interests; (xiv) intellectual property; and (xv) sanctions and anti-money laundering (and with certain
representations and warranties being repeated by reference to the facts and circumstances then existing on the
Closing Date (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement), each utilization date, on the first day
of each interest period and, in respect of such guarantor or borrower only, on the date on which a member of the
Group becomes a guarantor or borrower under the New Revolving Credit Facility).

**_Covenants_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants and related definitions (with
certain adjustments) that generally reflect the proposed terms of the Indenture. See “Description of the Notes—
_Certain Covenants.” In addition, the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also contains certain other_
affirmative and negative covenants. Set forth below is a brief description of such covenants, all of which are
subject to customary materiality, actual knowledge or other qualifications, exceptions and baskets.

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also contains a financial covenant, a brief description of which is
set out below.

**_Affirmative Covenants_**

The affirmative covenants include, among others: (i) providing certain financial information, including annual
audited and quarterly financial statements and compliance certificates; (ii) notification of events of default;
(iii) authorizations; (iv) compliance with laws; (v) payment of taxes; (vi) maintenance of pari passu ranking of
the New Revolving Credit Facility; (vii) maintenance of intellectual property; (viii) satisfaction of Guarantor
Coverage Test; (ix) further assurance provisions; and (x) an obligation to discharge the Existing Notes and
Existing Revolving Credit Facility.

**_Negative Covenants_**

The negative covenants include restrictions, among others, with respect to: (i) deliberately changing centres of
main interest; and (ii) non-compliance with economic sanctions.

**_Covenant Suspension_**

Certain of the covenants (and, in connection with a qualifying listing, other obligations or restrictions the Issuer
considers in good faith would not comply with applicable law, regulation or securities exchange requirements)
under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will be permanently suspended and the baskets set by
reference to a monetary amount under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will be permanently
increased by 50%, upon (i) a public offering of equity securities by any member of the Group (as defined in the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) or any holding company of a member of the Group other than the
Initial Investors and their Holding Companies (each as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement)
and an achievement of a Leverage Ratio (defined as the ratio of Consolidated Net Leverage on the date of such
determination to Consolidated EBITDA for the period of the most recent four fiscal quarters ending prior to the
date of such determination, each such term as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) equal to
or less than 2.25:1 (pro forma for any prepayment of certain indebtedness from the proceeds of such public
offering as if the proceeds of that public offering that have or will be applied in prepayment of the New Revolving
Credit Facility have been applied in prepayment of the New Revolving Credit Facility on the last day of that
Relevant Period (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement)) or (ii) an achievement by the Issuer
(or any of its affiliates) of a long-term corporate credit rating of Baa3/BBB- or better by Moody’s Investor
Services, Inc., Standard & Poor’s Investors Ratings Services or Fitch Ratings Ltd.

**_Mandatory Prepayment Requirements upon a Change of Control_**

On a Change of Control (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement), the Issuer shall promptly
notify the facility agent (the “Agent Notice”) who shall promptly notify the lenders under the New Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement and any issuing bank accordingly.

At the Issuer’s option (as specified in the Agent Notice), unless otherwise agreed between the Issuer and the
Majority Lenders under (and as defined in) the New Revolving Credit Facility either: (A) each lender shall be
entitled to cancel its commitments and require repayment of all its share of utilizations and payment of all amounts
owing to it under the Finance Documents (as defined under the New Revolving Credit Facility) and each issuing
bank shall be entitled to require than any letters of credit issued by it are prepaid and cancelled, in each case by
notification to the facility agent within 15 business days of the Agent Notice, whereupon, (i) the undrawn
commitments of such lender shall, by no less than 5 business days’ prior notice to the Issuer, be cancelled and
such lender shall have no obligation to fund or participate in any new utilization ((including in any new ancillary
facility or fronted ancillary facility) (other than a Letter of Credit issued or to be issued pursuant to a renewal
request or a utilization of an ancillary facility or a fronted ancillary facility to refinance any amount falling due
under an ancillary facility or a fronted ancillary facility) and, in the case of an issuing bank, such issuing bank
shall have no obligation to issue any Letter of Credit (other than a Letter of Credit issued or to be issued pursuant
to a renewal request); and (ii) on the date falling no later than 60 days after the Agent Notice, all outstanding
utilizations (including ancillary outstandings) together with accrued interest, and all other amounts accrued or
owing to such lender (or issuing bank, as the case may be) shall become immediately due and payable and the
relevant borrower will immediately prepay all utilizations and amounts provided by or owing to that lender and
procure that any cash collateral provided by that lender is released and any ancillary facility, fronted ancillary
facility and letter of credit is prepaid and cancelled; or (B) all outstanding undrawn commitments of each lender
shall be immediately cancelled and all outstanding utilizations and ancillary outstandings shall become
immediately due and payable, together with accrued interest and other amounts accrued to each lender (or that
lender in its capacity as issuing bank) under the Finance Documents (as defined in the New Revolving Credit
Facility).

**_Financial Covenants_**

If, on any quarter date in respect of the period of the most recent four consecutive financial quarters, the aggregate
amount outstanding of all loan utilizations under the New Revolving Credit Facility (or any other facility that has
the benefit of the springing financial covenant) (the “Springing Test Condition”) exceeds an amount equal to
40 per cent. of the total commitments under the New Revolving Credit Facility (or any other facility that has the
benefit of the springing financial covenant), the Issuer is required to confirm whether or not the Senior Secured
Net Leverage Ratio (defined as the ratio of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Indebtedness on the date of such
determination to Consolidated EBITDA for the period of the most recent four fiscal quarters ending prior to the
date of such determination, each such term as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) on such
quarter date for the period of last twelve months ending on that quarter date (subject to certain provisions and
adjustments) exceeds 4.75:1.

Any excess in the financial ratio test set out above will, subject to a grace period and certain cure and prevention
rights available to the Issuer under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, constitute an Event of Default
under (and as defined in) the New Revolving Credit Facility.

The Issuer is permitted to prevent or cure excesses in the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio as described above
by applying any cure amount (being amounts received by the Issuer in cash pursuant to any new equity or
permitted subordinated debt) towards increasing the amount of Consolidated EBITDA (an “EBITDA Cure”) or
towards decreasing Consolidated Senior Secured Net Indebtedness (a “Net Debt Cure”) (each as defined in the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). There is no requirement to apply any cure amount in prepayment of
the New Revolving Credit Facility. No more than four EBITDA Cures may be taken into account during the term
of the New Revolving Credit Facility with no more than two EBITDA Cures in any three successive testing
periods.

The Issuer is also permitted to prevent or cure excesses in the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio as described
above by recalculating the Springing Test Condition or Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio for any period at any
time based upon sufficient available information (including the latest internally available financial information
for an LTM period) and, if the Springing Test Condition is not met or the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio is
complied with at such time (due to prepayments of the New Revolving Credit Facility, cash or cash equivalents
on balance sheet or otherwise), the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio shall be deemed complied with and any
prior breach of such Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio or any Event of Default arising therefrom shall be deemed
cured. For any such calculation, the Issuer may give pro forma effect to certain transactions (and any permitted
adjustments to Consolidated EBITDA, Consolidated Senior Secured Net Indebtedness, the financial covenant or
the Springing Test Condition in connection therewith) for which the applicable calculation date has occurred
following the end of the period for which such calculation is made as if such transaction had been consummated
on the first day of such period.

**_Events of Default_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains substantially the same events of default, with certain
adjustments, as those applicable to the Notes as set forth in the section entitled “— Events of Default.” In addition,
the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains the following events of default:

  - non-compliance with the financial covenant that is not otherwise cured or prevented;

  - inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made;

  - breach of the Intercreditor Agreement; and

  - unlawfulness, repudiation, rescission, invalidity or unenforceability of the Finance Documents (as
defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) entered into in connection with the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

**Intercreditor Agreement**

**_General_**

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, the Issuer, Holdco,
the Guarantors and the Trustee are party to an Intercreditor Agreement between, among others, the agent, arrangers
and lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and the Security Agent.

147


-----

By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions
of, the Intercreditor Agreement and shall have deemed to have authorized the Trustee to enter into the ICA on its
behalf.

The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship
of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Issuer, the Guarantors and any
other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Third Party Security Provider (as
defined below), when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or Third Party Security Providers,
when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to which certain of that debt will
be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and provisions related
to the enforcement of shared security.

The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does
not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and not
the description that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes and of the Trustees. Capitalized
terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement.

For the purposes of this description:

“Senior Secured Group” shall mean the Issuer and any of its Restricted Subsidiaries.

References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include the Notes and any other notes, securities or other debt
instruments issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) has been
made available to or by a member of the Senior Secured Group which are designated by the Issuer as Senior
Secured Notes under the Intercreditor Agreement and references to the “Topco Notes” shall include any notes,
securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing has
been made available to or by a Topco Borrower (as defined below) which are designated by the Issuer as Topco
Notes.

The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “the Company” to refer to the Issuer and “Senior Secured Notes
**Liabilities” to refer to the Notes and certain other indebtedness of the Issuer. It uses the term “Topco” to refer to**
Holdco and any person that becomes a direct shareholder of the Issuer and which has acceded to the Intercreditor
Agreement as a Topco, and “Topco Notes Liabilities” to refer to any Topco Notes and certain other indebtedness
of Holdco.

_Ranking and Priority_

_Priority of Debts_

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by the Issuer and each other debtor (under the
Intercreditor Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than Holdco and any member of the Senior Secured
Group which is designated as a Topco Borrower under the Intercreditor Agreement) (a “Topco Borrower”))) to
the Secured Parties (as defined below) shall rank in right of priority and payment in the following order and are
postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows:

(i) first, liabilities owed to (i) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement or any future senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted
**Senior Secured Facilities Agreement”) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities”), (ii) the lenders, issuing**
banks, and ancillary lenders in relation to any future super senior facilities agreement (a “Permitted
**Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement”) and any hedge counterparty under a hedging agreement**
that on or after the Designation Date (as defined below) is designated by the Issuer as super senior
(together the “Super Senior Liabilities” and creditors thereof being the “Super Senior Creditors”),
(iii) the Trustee and any other entity acting as trustee or agent in relation to future senior secured notes
(each a “Senior Secured Notes Trustee”) (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee),
the holders of the Senior Secured Notes or future senior secured notes (the “Senior Secured Notes”) and
the Security Agent in relation to the Senior Secured Notes (the “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities”), (iv)
the lender under any future loan made by the issuer of any Senior Secured Notes (if so designated by the
Issuer in its discretion and not including, for the avoidance of doubt, the Issuer) to a member of the Senior
Secured Group for the purposes of on lending the proceeds of any Senior Secured Notes together with
any additional or replacement loan made on substantially the same terms (the “Senior Secured Notes
**Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), (v) the arrangers, agents, issuing banks and lenders under any cash**
management facility (a “Cash Management Facility” and the liabilities under a Cash Management

**Liabilities”), (vii) the lenders in relation to any future permitted second lien facility agreement (a**
